39427896.review:
[h1][url=store.steampowered.com/app/94300/The_Dream_Machine_Chapter_1__2/]The Dream Machine[/url] took a while to fully mature, evolving from an amateurish framework into a full-fledged adventure game.[/h1]

One of the game's main faults is arguably the egregious absence of animation throughout. Stiff characters stand perfectly still most of the time, with very little scenic animation support, if any, outside ambiant particles such as smoke or fireflies. Coupled with the lack of voice overs, this lends the game a remarkably static impression.

Despite the charming visuals, all rooms in initial chapters share the same square angles and overly basic layout, as if every simple scene was designed to fit in a tiny shoe box.

Over the extensive 7 years of development, the game's creators clearly gained experience in their craft and finally mastered the style in the last half of the game. This also means that the first 3 chapters are consequently rather dull in comparison.

[u]Chapter 1[/u] serves as a basic introduction to the game's settings, main character Victor and classic gameplay mechanics.

[u]Chapter 2[/u] suddenly becomes freaky as the game slowly begins to reveal its plot and the meaning behind its title. These first too chapters felt unspectacular to me.

[u]Chapter 3[/u] suffers from a bad case of picking up anything in sight for no valid reason other than it might come in handy later. Victor performs mundane errands for numerous clones nearly the entire time, including some straining puzzles, though nothing illogical. The story still isn't very compelling so far, gameplay is entirely linear.

[u]Chapter 4[/u] is where the game finally takes form and turns genuinely good. With more interesting puzzles, it now feels like an authentic adventure game. This chapter presents original ideas, such as a special wall in the dream section where players can rearrange the order of rooms.

[u]Chapter 5[/u] wastes little time in the real world and sends players directly to the good bits. Unfortunately half of it is a dry sci-fi world that features a clever but overused character scaling mechanic. The second and arguably much bigger "half" is great, however. The player is now handling multiple quests simultaneously, centered around a larger environment and more detailed characters.

From hereon the game also proposes a much needed diversity of textures and materials in the scene compositions, more dynamic camera angles and better lighting. Looks great!

[u]Chapter 6[/u] turns into a very imaginative introspective exploration, and feels nothing like the previous five chapters. It lets you revisit most of the previous locations, though not many of them turn out to be really useful. This chapter also makes astute reuse of previously introduced mechanics or solutions.

[u]Chapter 7[/u] proposes a short epilogue to the latter chapter. It presents potential for an extremely difficult choice but offers none to make, ending the game in a disappointingly passive situation that feels somewhat unresolved.

[h1]Positive[/h1]
[list]
[*] Some intriguing dialogues and story beats
[*] Original art style and premise
[*] Significantly improves over every chapter
[/list]

[h1]Neutral[/h1]
[list]
[*] Creepy looking characters (good or bad, depending on taste)
[*] Some straining puzzles, though nothing illogical
[*] Not a family-friendly adventure (some unexpected moments of relatively intense gore and sexual matters)
[/list]

[h1]Negative[/h1]
[list]
[*] No voice overs
[*] Lack of animations
[*] Buggy Flash-based engine produces frequent freezes at startup
[*] Dull first half of the game
[*] Clunky old school UI (no continue option when returning to the game, must manually load save)
[*] Annoying scream during dream transitions disrupts the mood
[*] Disappointingly evasive game ending
[/list]

As an avid dreamer and adventure gamer, I expected this game to be a perfect match for my taste. Instead I met a slowly evolving budget production that only partially fulfilled my curiosity and felt like a student project for the first half. I still recommend it bittersweetly to fans of the genre as the game does improve significantly.

39133855.review:
Seven years in the making, The Dream Machine first saw the light of day in 2010 and finally concluded in 2017. The wait was certainly worth it, and viewed as a complete package the game stands as one of the finest point and click adventures ever made. Beautifully hand crafted models and sets made out of cardboard, wood, felt and clay, The Dream Machine has a very distinct look and is clearly a labor of love. 

A psychedelic plot where you explore the dreams of the tenants of an apartment complex being controlled by a machine built for the explicit purpose of mapping a theoretical shared dream world, the game really goes places in terms of settings and story. Wildly imaginative, funny and scary with a satisfying and absolutely bonkers finale that I won’t give away because it is so absurd, this gem is one you shouldn’t miss.

38211583.review:
Dopo aver finito tutti i capitoli di Dream Machine mi sento lacerato nel profondo dell'anima. E nel senso buono del termine.

Si tratta un'avventura grafica di quelle toste, di quelle vere, di quelle che stimolano il cervello del giocatore e non gli servono tutto sotto forma di film interattivo o "gioco esplorativo". L'utilizzo degli oggetti, dell'ambiente e soprattutto della materia grigia sarà fondamentale per procedere.

La trama di questo titolo, poi, è qualcosa di meraviglioso. Credo sia una delle più intelligenti, interessanti ed innovative che abbia trovato da moltissimo tempo a questa parte. La carica emotiva, inoltre, è enorme e alla fine ci si trova per forza a riflettere su tutto ciò che si è visto e sentito.

Non riesco a trovare un difetto che sia uno, quindi non posso che affermare che Dream Machine sia un capolavoro, assolutamente da consigliare a tutti gli amanti delle avventure grafiche e, più in generale, a coloro che vogliono imbarcarsi in un viaggio che non dimenticheranno tanto facilmente.

遊戲氣氛渲染得非常棒，搭上獨特的粘土風格、詭異的背景音樂和出乎意料的劇情展開，在遊玩時常常會有耳目一新的感覺。這遊戲和Jan Švankmajer(捷克的電影導演，擅長粘土動畫)的電影風格相當像，如果看過這位導演的電影，就不難想像這款遊戲怪誕的畫面與劇情。

個人覺得這遊戲最令人驚艷的是它光怪陸離的情節，由於是夢境的探索，所以在這六個章節中主角會進到各種「超現實」空間，像是回憶中的破碎小屋、驚悚版的童話小鎮，還有像電影《黑客帝國》般的空間維度等等，這些夢境沒有任何重複的地方，而且帶來的感受也完全不同，可以說是非常用心的作品。

36328170.review:
[b]Один из самых интересных и круто сделанных квестов, которые мне довелось попробовать.[/b]

В нём замечательно практически всё - замечательное звуковое сопровождение, местами очень сложные, но всё равно логичные головоломки, крайне интересный сюжет, необычное даже для квестов визуальное исполнение. Если честно, я даже не знаю с чем этот квест можно сравнивать, если по визуальной части, то на ум приходит разве что Neverhood. Поначалу очень непривычно, по со временм привыкаешь, и даже входишь во вкус. Всё же в пластилиновой анимации есть своеобразная изюминка, придающая квесту огромный шмат оригинальности, при этом никак ей не мешающей.

По части геймплея этому квесту поистине нет равных - продумано всё до мельчайших деталей. Можно сделать/попробовать практически все варианты которые взбредут в голову. Даже на самые идиотские действия игрока есть своя строго тематическая реплика персонажей/пояснения. Квест проходить действительно интересно и сложно. Каких-либо абсурдных решений головоломок я за всю игру не заметил - всё до предела логично, хоть и далеко не всегда сразу допирает как решать головоломки, и что вообще требуется сделать дальше для продвижения. 

Также очень круто сделана атмосфера. Квест хоть и не сделан как ужастик, местами всё же нагоняет крипоты. Я так понял, что квест в большей степени ориентирован на старшую игровую аудиторию, исходя из его содержания. Стиль повествования сухой и непредвзятый, без каких бы то ни было моральных нравоучений и указаний что хорошо, а что плохо. Скорее выполнен в форме непрерывного повествования. Выполнен очень хорошо, должен заметить, честь и хвала сценаристам.

Из минусов могу выделить разве что тот момент, что квест сделан во флеше, или что там он использует, из-за чего процессор моего ноутбука жарил так, что на на нём можно было кипятить чай. Но это не очень большой минус, и претензии скорее к моему железу, чем к игре.


Подводя итог, скажу что квест действительно один из самых лучших в истории игростроения, понравится всем ценителям глубоких историй, и хорошо продуманных деталей. Но никак не подойдёт тем, кто хочет просто расслабиться и позалипать во что-нибудь эдакое, потому что в нём частенько нужно некисло так напрягать мозги, и тестировать различные варианты чуть ли не до бесконечности.

Для квестов это 10/10.

36312948.review: I bought this game for the unique visuals, but some of the environments are boring considering it's about dreams. 36148117.review:
It's a weird feeling to finally finish this episodic game that I started playing a couple of years ago. Not only because it's a sad feeling to finish a game you've been coming back to and exploring for so long, but also because I would argue that TDM is, despite some minor flaws, one of the most artistically fulfilling and aesthetically original games I've ever played.

First of all, the design of the game is obviously the thing that everybody will mention. But the cardboard-and-clay-style is worth mentioning at length. Because TDM's highly unique style is not just a gimmick, it also enhances every inch of the games dream-focused plotline, making it a game that is both otherworldy beautiful and right-out dreadful and terrifying.

However, sometimes the game is a bit off - some dialogue and plotting can feel a bit lacking, as well as some minor bugs breaking the immersion somewhat. 

A few puzzles can also feel a bit too obtuse and unforgiving, which is a shame, considering that TDM also packs some of the absolutely BEST puzzles I've seen in a recent adventure game. At it's best, TDM uses it's ominous dream logic and creates some immensly satisfying brain teasers that are both perfect within the story and interesting and fun to solve.
 
All in all, TDM is a game that starts out as something I figured for a clichéed dream story, but soon evolves into a literal existential nightmare, filled with twists and turns that will haunt you for a long time to come. Highly recommended.

36135448.review:
[h1]Short version: 70%[/h1]
The Dream Machine is an old-school point ‘n’ click that really likes its long-winded musings about the nature of human existence. Although its philosophical nature and clay animation style may classify it as an “artsy” game, its adventure game bits also hide some interesting moments.

[h1]Long version:[/h1]
It is difficult to review The Dream Machine, because while it starts as a seemingly normal adventure game, eventually it transforms into a naval-gazing exploration laced in existentialist metaphors.

Said adventure game bits bring us back to the golden age of point ‘n’ clicks, not just with the classic handmade clay animation but also with the tedious pixel hunting and some decent dose of moon logic. These early, plot-focused chapters introduce our protagonist, Victor, who recently moved to a new apartment building with his pregnant wife, but soon discovers that an evil machine is feeding on the dreams of all tenants.
From there, our job is to enter the dreams of everyone in the apartment, and as the story goes, the writing style detaches itself more and more from reality (and sanity), shedding many adventure game bits to end in a series of philosophical monologues on human existence.

It is easy to dismiss the game as an art project, especially in later chapters where the graphical filters go on a rampage. Still, its uniqueness will have a lasting impression on anyone (assuming the game does not crash on them), and considering it is one of the primary goals of art, we can say that The Dream Machine is a rather successful project.

35721381.review:
This is a really fantastic point & click adventure game for fans of the genre. The whole thing is built up of clay figures and backgrounds, spruced up further with bits of paper, moss, fabric, twigs, leaves, and other materials, which gives it a unique and kind of nostalgic look, reminding you of classic claymation. Amazingly, it's built up in Flash. I've experienced the occasional glitch where dialogue text repeatedly pops up, sometimes white screens where the game apparently crashes, and some bad slowdown on certain heavily layered graphics, but mostly it's extremely stable.

You play as Victor Neff, a young guy who just moved into a new apartment with his pregnant girlfriend, and discover something crazy. I'll avoid saying more than that, as the story takes many surprising turns. It took a bit of playing for me to gauge what kind of story the game was going for - the static clay figures look a little grotesque, and I was expecting a more cartoonish plot. Instead, the game gets quite serious, even dark at points, and tells a fairly mature tale. A good deal of it reminded me of I Have No Mouth And I Must Scream, another excellent adventure game.

It's a very challenging adventure game. A few times now, I've had to look up online help to get further. The game lets you switch hints from the main character on or off, but even switched on, it can get very difficult to figure out. Still, never unfairly so.

If you miss point and click adventuring, this game should provide you with a great many hours of gameplay.

35122801.review:
The Dream Machine is a very complex game. The point and click controls and puzzle solving may lead one to believe, at first glance, that this game is a standard, by the numbers adventure game with a stop-motion aesthetic. But much like the apartment in which this game takes place, there is a lot more lying underneath the surface, waiting to be discovered.

The story is deep, thought-provoking and highly engaging, albeit very surreal and a touch depressing towards the end. This game is one that requires a lot of thought and a lot of patience, because starting around the second chapter, most of the time you will spend playing this game will involve backtracking, and if you are clueless about what is going on, the game can become somewhat tedious and frustrating. All in all, however, the cleverness and surreal gameplay should be enough to keep things interesting.

Mild Spoilers: This game contains a lot of claymation gore and a bittersweet ending.  Do not play if either of these things upset you.

35120905.review:
I'm [still] intrigued. I purchased this almost exclusively for the artistry alone so I'm willing to overlook any sort of mechanical flaws; real or perceived (I don't perceive any though). I love this game so far. It's unique and for anyone who knows about claymation, it takes FOREVER.. so kudos. The game has this mysterious element to it that - so far - is not over the top. I *want* to know what happens next. I credit the storytelling and interactive dialogue. The walking may seem cumbersome if one is expecting typical smooth motions of a point-and-click but remember it's the process of this type of animation. 

ETA: Finally finished this game. FINALLY. Toward the end, it was more of a chore than it should have been. The story collapses as you get into the side quests of various dreams. I felt as though the integration and use of those elements could have been better, more smoothly executed. The artwork also kind of suffers at the end, as well; a bit disappointing as that's what initially drew me in. 

The puzzles were great; I enjoyed those quite a bit (just not in the last chapter). There is unexpected "nudity" and disturbing content toward and at the very end. If you're a woman, more than likely the ending is offensive on some level. If you're a man, creeped out. Regardless, a very wtf moment for everyone. [spoiler]Traversing the vag[inal] canal of one's own mother is not something that should ever be explored on any sort of level; contemplative, literal or metaphorical.[/spoiler] The story would've done fine w/o that oddball inclusion. There is also "gore." I'm putting quotations around the terms as this is claymation and you'd have to admit to limitations in creating that kind of element using that particular medium.

Having said all of that, there is another disturbing moment but one that you kind of feel coming throughout the game. It made me truly question my motives in the game and I enjoyed that opportunity to briefly reflect on that. All in all, I'd still give a thumbs-up for the artistry and puzzles.

35110786.review:
Прекрасний інді-квест, який створили всього дві людини. Довгих сім років вони трудилися над грою і я надзвичайно радий, що їм вдалося довести свій задум до кінця. В результаті ми отримали одного з кращих представників свого жанру.

Головною особливістю The Dream Machine є те, що майже всі моделі гри спочатку робилися з глини, а вже потім оцифровувалися. Чесно кажучи, обличчя персонажів вийшли доволі страшненькі, але локації у такому виконанні - ну дуже симпатичні, з якимось унікальним шармом! Сюжет теж не підвів - тут вам і фантастика, і детектив, і драма.
Усього в грі 6 епізодів. Перші проходяться досить швидко, але, з часом The Dream Machine набирає обертів, епізоди стають довшими, загадки складнішими, а під кінець починається справжній квестовий хардкор. На щастя, автори придумали досить оригінальну систему підказок, яка допоможе пройти складні відрізки.

Без вагань ставлю The Dream Machine позитивну оцінку і рекомендую її усім любителям квестів. Але не дайте обдурити себе - незважаючи на "ляльковість", у грі вистачає кривавих та дорослих моментів.

This game is crudely beautiful. Lots of videogames branch off a very similar artistic nature, but The Dream Machine is incredibly unique. 

Pros

Cons

34065096.review:
[i]This is a review of the full game[/i]

[h1]Artstyle[/h1] 

Unusual, intricate, sometimes strangely beautiful, sometimes downright weird (towards the end). The main protagonist is stop-motion animated clay, the backgrounds are all handcrafted from a variety of materials. It takes some getting used to but it really grew on me. 

The music and sounds are very well done and enhance the atmosphere of the game. There's no voice acting, you have to read the dialogue which sometimes is a bit tedious but on the whole is well written and not too long.


[h1]Story[/h1]

Also unusual and sometimes weird, heh. 

You just moved into a new appartment with your pregnant wife and you soon realise that something's not right. What starts out as a bit of a detective story slowly turns into something more sinister. You are definitely no hero but you are trying to do the right thing even if that has sometimes unintended consequences. 

In my opinion, the last part of the story is the weakest and it would have been better if the game had ended with the 5th part but YMMV. But up to that part it is interesting and darker than usual in adventure games. This is not a happy story, not suitable for children (there's death and other rather disturbing things).


[h1]Puzzles[/h1] 

Hard but not unfair. This is no game for newbies to the genre. The individual chapters are not linear for the most part, you can "work" on several puzzles at the same time and sometimes there are several ways you can solve a puzzle.

There is no in-game help, no hints besides what other people tell you and no hotspot viewer, although the latter is not too important since there is no pixel hunting in this game. I never got stuck because I overlooked something. I did get stuck a few times, though, and twice so severely that I had to stop playing to sleep over it. For the last three chapters, there are no walkthroughs available, so be advised, if you get frustrated easily this is probably not the game for you. 

The puzzles in chapter 5 are outstanding. Very mild spoiler: [spoiler]You can change your size in this chapter which allows for some really interesting puzzle designs.[/spoiler]


[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Very simple, just point and click. You drag items from your inventory (appears at the top of the screen) to where you want to use them. I would have liked the option to double click exits to move through screens or at least to run faster. Instead, you move with one speed through the screens which slows the game down considerably in some areas, especially chapter 5 which requires you to run around a lot. 


[h1]Summary[/h1]

I liked this game quite a bit. A lot of work went into the backgrounds and it shows. The puzzles are hard and you often have several to solve at once, the developers did a very good job here. The finale to the story was a bit weak, in my opinion, but the overall story is captivating. The game is well worth its full price if you look at my game time but there are frequent sales as well. 

[b]I recommend this game for adventure game veterans who are willing to take their time with this game.[/b]

34048378.review:
*This is a review of the full game*

Beautiful and emotional point-and-click adventure with some of the best and most charming dialogue I have seen in recent years. The game is filled to the brim with creative puzzles that are sometimes almost too clever for their own good. It starts out a little bit sluggish but becomes very exciting as soon as the plot starts to kick in. Visually the game is stunning, especially the environments deserve notable praise. The characters, in my opinion, maybe looked a bit too crude to be immediately likeable, but they quickly grow on the player emotionally as the story progresses. The dialogue is immersive and well-written, rich with both clever comedy and emotional baggage. The sound quality is a tad crude but is well-implented and extremely effective in serving its purpose.
The game has classic point-and-click gameplay but also succeeds in providing uniquely creative and smart puzzles that are sometimes so clever that players will probably overlook the solutions that are right under their noses.

Chapters 1 to 4 get a five-star rating from me. Well-designed puzzles and enough balance in difficulty and effort not to be slowed down quite too much. There's a beautiful build-up in tension of the story during these first four chapters and there have been moments where I felt the game really reached out and spoke to me emotionally. It would be an understatement to say that a lot of big corporately financed AAA game studios could learn a thing or two from Anders Gustafsson's magnificent writing and narrative design. 

Chapter 5
Although this chapter is probably the richest in content and length, this is where the quality of gamedesign goes subtly downhill, with some areas (like Mr. Willard's dream) being very uncommunicative to the player as to which actions to pursue next. For me, this led to frustrating hours sluggishly walking from screen to screen trying to solve puzzles that were already finished for the time being. This is also the first chapter where the game becomes a bit less linear and expects the player to backtrack between different dreams, without explicitly communicating it to the player, which seemed a bit counterintuitive at the time.

Chapter 6
From a gameplay perspective, there is just way, way too much backtracking in this chapter (coming from a person who loves backtracking-heavy genres such as metroidvania games). The game demands that the player revisits the same characters over and over and make them repeat the same things in different words over and over only to receive the tiniest of breadcrumbs leading to the next clue. Once you've finally got all the 'breadcrumbs' you have to put them in a certain order in a very far-off place, without having any clear indication as a player whether your setup is correct or not, leading to potentially endless hours of backtracking. At this point, regardless of my emotional and time investments so far, I would have put this game down if it weren't for the "Quick Travel" option and a walkthrough by my side.
In retrospect, this whole chapter kind of irked and confused me. The story abruptly becomes more abstract and philosophical. By the time I had reached the finale of the game, I had become so out of touch with the game world's inherent logic and 'reality' that I couldn't tell whether aborting a duplicate fetus with an adult mind was a good or a bad thing to do in regards to the context of the story and characters. The ending also striked me as rather dark and sad, and I hope that the rumours of a possible alternate, happier ending are true. Ultimately, I might just have been a bit worn out at this point and felt that the same charm and beauty of the first four chapters seemed a bit absent in the final chapter.

Final verdict: 
Despite the disappointment I felt with the final chapter, I would not have wanted to miss out on this gem of a game. Anyone with a disposition for visually beautiful and unique games with deeply emotional narratives should not miss this one!

33983533.review:
The first thing I want to say about this game is that it's clearly a labour of love. It has a wonderful, unique art style and great overall puzzle design. But what I'm most surprised about is how much I enjoyed the story. I went in cold and didn't know what to expect. My only clue about the aesthetic was the moody, svankmejer style claymation. And indeed the game has dark, foreboding and creepy moments - that are excellently done. Because they are interspersed in a tale that surprised me with its maturity and understatement. While at the same time being full of creativity and wonderment. Long story short, the writing is good! 

And frankly good writing is more rare than you'd think. Since the Lucasarts hayday, most point and click adventures have tended toward goofy, shticky humor that makes me cringe as often as not. This game has a story it wants to tell and does so in a believable way. 

The puzzles are solid. Mostly right in the sweet spot of being thoughtful but not frustrating. I've played a lot of point and clicks. The Dream Machine follows the unspoken rules of puzzle design to give players zany ideas that still make sense in context. It's a little light on hints, but your goals are clear. 

The art design should be made into a coffee table book. It is unique and gorgeous. Just like the game as a whole!  Also a shoutout to the sound design for adding the same unique yet familiar ambiance that the visuals have. 

Listen, I'm a jaded gamer. I wasn't expecting much when I picked this up on sale. But after finishing, I know it's one of the classics of it's genre for this era. I've played enough to know that true classics are few and far between. 

So put it on your wishlist, and buy it when you have the dough. On sale or not, it's worth the ticket price. These developers deserve the money to keep making games. Hopefully more claymation point and click :)

I played the whole game and LOVED it!
I bought 2 chapters of the game on sale, and somehow missed that this was an incomplete game. So had to buy the rest of the chapters full price, I think. Well, luckily they were all available, and I didn't have to wait for them to be released, like some people did. But that was a bit of a trick I didn't like.

For me one of the selling points was that this is a handmade game shot with stop motion. I loved how it was made, all the backgrounds and close-ups (sometimes quite creepy - like the close-up of the vampire). Sometimes would stop in one place and try to guess what material they made certain things with. Also, really loved the soundtrack.

When I bought it, I was a bit worried that maybe they put all their energy into making a visually appealing game with clay and other materials (because that was a big selling point for them), but didn't put much effort into the story. However, the story was GREAT! And it was quite a long game too, which was pleasant. So many twists and turns, sometimes really unsettling and creepy parts, which I loved. Generally, the theme of dreams, getting into people's dreams, is just such and interesting one - there is so much you can do with it!

The puzzles to me seemed classic for point&click games: some logical, some not quite. There were moments when I would aimlessly wander around a location to see what I was missing. Some puzzles took quite a long time, but I think it's fine for point&click games.

Overall, it's an amazing experience and I hope you enjoy it too!

32827061.review:
Facciamo una piccola premessa: ho acquistato i primi due capitoli di questo gioco a 99 centesimi, subito dopo aver giocato il primo capitolo ho comprato terzo e quarto capitolo. Non appena uscito il quinito anche lui è finito dritto nella mia libreria ed ho atteso, infine, l'ultimo sesto capitolo uscito poco tempo fa.

Il primo acquisto riguardante questo gioco è stato effettuato nel 2014, l'ultimo nel 2017. Durante tutto questo tempo ho atteso intrepido di poter finire The Dream Machine e ve lo dico subito, ne vale assolutamente la pena e l'attesa.

The Dream Machine è un classico punta e clicca basata ad enigmi che però di classico ha davvero poco. Infatti il videogioco è stato creato interamente sfruttando creta e cartoni per realizzare i personaggi e gli scenari animati in stop motion.

Questa scelta da un tocco di bellezza unica a questo gioco, le immagine che ne risultano sono incredibilmenti forti a livello espressivo, sopratutto per la scelta cromatica e la consistenza che l'ambiente e i personaggi hanno.

Spesso quando si parla di punta e clicca ad enigmi si pensa a giochi difficili e contorti solo per il gusto di esserlo. Ed è vero, The Dream Machine ha degli enigmi difficili e complessi ma tutto è studiato bene: ogni capitolo inizia in modo semplice e vi guiderà automaticante a migliorare nella risoluzione degli enigni finali di ogni capitolo.

Passiamo però al punto di forza: la storia. Non ho mai vissuto un'avventura così profonda e ben studiato. Una trama ben studiata, con ottime radici di ricerca, citazioni di un certo livello e un pizzico di sfondamento della quarta parete. La comunicazione di questo gioco è ad altissimi livelli. Vi farà pensare, vi entrarà sotto pelle, vi farà riflettere, sicuramente vi farà immedesimare nel personaggio protagonista della storia.

Dutante le tante ore di gioco, mai noiose e sempre avvincenti, vi troverete di fronte a cose che, davvero, nemmeno potete immaginare. Ogni capitolo ha un suo background e un suo significato, la storia e la trama si evolvono attraverso ognuno di loro culminando in un capitolo finale che vi farà pensare ma sicuramente vi farà emozionare.

Consigliato? Ovviamente. Ma ci vuole consapevolezza, non è un gioco qualunqe, non è un gioco per tutti. Se volete giocarlo saprà emozionarvi, con pazienza, con calma, vi guiderà attraverso un'avventura che difficilmente troverete all'interno di un altro videogioco.

32801065.review:
[b](Please note this is a review for the full game.)[/b]

If we're being honest here, I don't always finish the games I review. Sometimes it's because they're too awful, sometimes because I know how I feel about them early on, and sometimes because they're just not for me. But I made a point to finish The Dream Machine and I'm very glad I did, because what happens in that final chapter feels like the real game, with everything that leads up to it a long prelude in retrospect. That's not speaking ill of the early chapters, mind you, that's giving the impressive final act the recognition it deserves.

Victor Neff has moved into a small apartment building with his pregnant wife Alicia. They're trying to prepare for their new arrival, but a chance discovery by Victor reveals a dark plot lurking within their home. The titular dream machine holds the power to invade dreams to nefarious ends, and Victor gets wrapped up in a struggle against it that has greater stakes than anyone could imagine. What starts as a quest to rescue his neighbors becomes a battle for life and understanding of the secrets of existence.

The stakes are sky high here, which makes the decision to portray them in clay and craftwork all the more remarkable. The Dream Machine does a pretty good job of hiding what its characters and backdrops are crafted from but this comes at a cost, usually with a lack of detail or animation to cover for the shortcomings of budget stop-motion animation. Don't expect a lot of expressive movement or dense scenes to explore, but expect plenty of atmosphere from everything you encounter. Even pleasant scenes are given a sinister, off-putting feel by the black-eyed stares of people and waxy sheen on common objects. And you'd better believe this aesthetic is used to full effect when needed.

It's the tone of The Dream Machine that's most noticeable about it, starting off rather innocuously with breakfast and chores, and then dropping hints at darker things and strange plots. By the time you're dream-hopping through unfamiliar landscapes the atmosphere has turned plenty creepy, and this unease ramps up exponentially to the conclusion. Throughout it all the characters involved will take the incredible events unfolding around them in stride, adding to the appropriately dreamlike feel of the whole affair. This mastery of tone is what keeps the game deeply affecting even when wrestling with puzzles or wandering about wondering what to do next.

As expertly as the dream motifs are used here though, you won't need to worry about any loopy dream logic to the puzzles. You'll find a fair number of items as you point-and-click your way through your quest but most have perfectly reasonable uses. The hardest threads to follow are when characters ask you favors or instruct you to handle something, because the solution usually involves some improvisation outside of the expected solution. I got stuck on a few puzzles for awhile, such as trying to find a substitute for tomato juice for a drink and locating bait for a fishing rod I didn't realize I needed. You may very well need to consult a walkthrough from time to time, because while the puzzles make sense they don't always make it clear how to do what you realize you need to do.

That would normally be a knock against an adventure game but the puzzles in The Dream Machine are extremely clever, and sometimes the difficulty comes from how clever they are. You'll come across a few gimmicks that are used to incredible effect, like one where you can rearrange rooms in a house and another where you can shrink or grow yourself. It's entirely possible you've seen these in other games but I promise you they weren't used as well as they are here. That uniqueness makes them harder to solve but seeing where the puzzle and associated plot go are more than worth the hassle.

Now, the plot is probably the strangest part of this game, and also what makes it so brilliant in the end. I gave you the opener up above, and it should be no surprise that this hook leads you to explore the dreams of the building's other residences. In general the chapters of the game are divided by dream, with each resident having a different theme to their dream realm. That means most of the game is occupied with working through the puzzles of a realm until you reach the goal and somehow free something up in the real world to allow access to the next. There's a clear progression here that feels like a proper quest, with little to distract from going through the motions.

All that changes in the final chapter. Suddenly the game takes a sharp philosophical and metaphysical turn, ejecting the clear reality/dream divide and dredging up a whole mess of pathos for your avatar Victor. It was off-putting at first, and not in the appropriate way that the art style is. I wondered if the final chapter had even been made by the same people, the gulf was so great. But then the puzzles started back up, even more involved and clever than before, sending me through colorful new areas and revisiting old ones. It built to a conclusion kicked off by a shockingly unpleasant scene, one that can hardly be called a happy ending but is maybe as perfect for the game as is possible. A lot of symbolism and subtext I hadn't really noticed before came to light and I started to reconsider how I felt about the game as a whole. As in, I started to wonder if I loved it instead of just liked it.

It's a lengthy journey of ten to twelve hours, and not all of that is going to be smooth sailing. You might have trouble connecting to the strangely alien characters at first, or you might get stuck on one of more involved puzzles each dream tends to have. But the foundations are solid and the atmosphere is great, and I assure you it all builds to something that's worth experiencing if you have the stomach for it. Fans of games that challenge them on many levels will find their match here, between the clever puzzles and the volatile story. I didn't think I was one of those fans, but as it turns out, The Dream Machine showed me a great many things I did not expect.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/audish#curation]curation page[/url]!

The Dream Machine seems like it's destined to be a classic of the point-and-click adventure genre, with a compelling narrative (which I won't spoil here) which unfolds naturally. I genuinely had no idea where the plot was going when it started and the conclusion to chapter one drew me in.

32758832.review:
This review is for the full game.

This is a really well-done "point and click" adventure game. It was put together in stages over several years, and it has the resulting depth and breadth that other games of this type rarely do. The handmade visual style is unlike anything I've seen in this type of game, and has a vivid, reach-out-and-you-can-touch-it solidness to it.

One thing worth stating upfront is that THIS GAME IS NOT FOR KIDS. I mention this because I'm a fan of the Amanita Design games that have a similar 2-D approach, like Machinarium, Botanicula and Samorost 3. Those have some spooky elements, but mostly they're kid-friendly as well as having challenging puzzles for adults. Dream Machine goes WAY farther into a dark, grisly, sometimes horror-tinged realm -- and I think it is exclusively for adults.

The plusses of the game are many. I was surprised that the creators were able to sustain long-form storytelling over the entire series. Every little element in the early chapters is of-a-piece and builds toward the puzzles as well as enhancing the story over the full course of the game. It's extremely cohesive and cumulative in how it unfolds.

The puzzles and Zork-like adventure aspects of this game are very satisfying. There are only a few puzzles that require structural analytic thinking (like trying to figure out how to arrange transistors in a box to get the right amount of current). Rather, most of the puzzles require direct observation of the locations and situations, with logical solutions that reward you for paying attention. You will need to retrace your steps sometimes to really LOOK at things, but the game designers don't hide anything in obscure places. Everything you need is upfront, as long as you're paying attention and thinking things through. 

I love it when games like this have that sense of FAIR PLAY, where they give you JUST ENOUGH but NOT TOO MUCH to figure things out. Dream Machine strikes that balance very well. Some of the puzzles might require you, aptly enough, to sleep on them for a bit, but that's about all. (I got stuck once due to my misunderstanding of how a laser beam was directed at a wall, so I looked for a walkthrough, but saw too much and felt like a jerk for spoiling the fun for myself. After that, I was happy to solve the rest of the game on my own, even though I almost got stuck later -- something to do with a character asking me to make a sandwich....)

On the NEGATIVE side: The aspect of the game I found most irksome was the text. Though well-written and sometimes very witty (as with the phone calls to God scene), the constant click, click,click of the dialogue between characters approach tedium at times. The designers seem to have learned to keep things brisk over the course of the game, and I felt like dialogue wasn't *quite* as obnoxious in the latter chapters. Since the game doesn't have any voice-over acting, but just text, at least you can click through as fast as you like. Still, I wish they had given you an option to get a single-screen display of all the dialogue on the 2nd pass, instead of having to click-click-click-click-click each time.

All in all, this is one of the most surprisingly ambitious and "Wow I can't believe how much game is packed into this game" experiences I've had with a low-cost, 2-D, indie game purchase. No regrets, it was worth the time and money, and I felt like I got to experience an original, well-constructed, creative-risk-taking story in the process.

32541864.review:
I'm writing this about the entire game. In fact, if I was writing this about the first 2 chapters, I woud've been hopeful. "So much potential", I'd write, "such an interesting premise!" But no, the full game, after 7 years in development, is an utter mess that gets more teious and boring to play the further it goes.

First two chapters establish the premise of a strange horror mystery dream thriller sci-fi tale with not particularly good writing, but one that fits the mood and stop motion looks. Game doesn't really have a very strong focus on puzzle solving, moves at consistant pace and establishes an intersting setup.

Chapter 3 is where things start falling apart. Game enforces more teidous walking back and forth, asks for obscure puzzle solutions and doesn't present a particularly interesting story, but at least it moves the premise forward. Chapter 4, on the other hand, feels like a step back in the right direction and apart from more poorly designed puzzles at times, feels like the concept developing and game design of the game evolving.

And then Chapter 5 happens and everything comes to a grinding halt. Game stumbles and falls flat on its face, pace killed completely, initial setup almost all but forgotten, tone sent completely off the hinges. And if you manage to suffer from Chapter 5, you're greeted not with a return to form, initial promise fullfilled and game logically concluded, but with a mess of self-discovery, pseudo-psychological "smart" sequences, scene borrowed from Kubrik and an ending quote from Radiohead. I suppose, it's easy to forget what you were doing in the first place in 7 years of making of the game, but maybe doing something almost seemingly unrelated to anything before, isn't a good answer.

It's not a particularly fun adventure game, with really tedious "puzzles" starting in the last chapters. It's not a good story, because the storyline falls apart somewhere after midpoint and it's not particularly well written. And it's very definitely not worth time it requires to suffer through it all. Which is a shame, really, because it had "such an amazing premise".

32117869.review:
+ Unique claymation graphics
+ Interesting and varied settings
+ Brilliant and mostly logical puzzles (Yes, even in the dreams)
+ Seamless transition between chapters
+ Writing gradually improves

- Main character is too much of a blank slate
- Glitches
- Game crashes without warning
- Unsatisfying ending
- Game window can't be minimized
- No inventory shortcuts, even for things like keys that you use often (you always have to click and drag)

* Lots of horror elements, so the squeamish or easily spooked should take note

Good news: if you buy this game now, you won't have to wait years for its completion anymore.There's no need to worry if you're just picking it up—the transition from chapter to chapter is impressively seamless given the long development time. The exact same environments can be used without any jarring shift in graphics thanks to the claymation, too. I bought it early on and waited for it to be finished before starting, which is good because the game never offers a recap of what came before.

Let's start with the obvious: The Dream Machine looks incredible, even with the annoying black bars at the sides of the screen. A tremendous amount of love went into making this, and it shows. Plus thanks to the premise, the setting of each chapter changes drastically, which keeps things memorable and fresh from start to finish even if the worlds you explore lack the fullblown surrealism of actual dreams.

The downside of the beautiful claymation is that it's difficult to see which objects you can interact with or not. There's no button to highlight all the hotspots you can check out, so your only option is to move your mouse along the screen and wait for things to light up. Worse is when a smaller component of a whole is what you need to find. Let's say you're supposed to click on the handle of a bicycle. If you scroll over the bike the entire object will light up, which disguises the fact that the handle yields a totally different interaction when clicked. It's needlessly frustrating, especially when the problem could so easily be circumvented by the main character giving a hint like "the handles on the bike are loose."

Speaking of the main character, he's really not a strong lead. Victor has no job, no ambitions, and no apparent hobbies other than perhaps music (which you would never know if not for the guitar in his apartment). You can choose to play him as someone mostly kind and helpful, or be a complete jerk at every available opportunity. If this had noticeable consequences on Victor's behaviour in the scripted sections it might be interesting, but they seem to play out the same regardless. Even Victor's descriptions of the things you click on lack personality: "There's nothing remarkable about it." "It's a chair." "I used this X to Y."

Chapter 6 makes a last-ditch effort to provide him with a blandly generic backstory, but by the end of the final chapter I still didn't have a clear idea of who Victor *was*, which detracted significantly from the ending―an ending which seems to offer an obvious opportunity for a final, meaningful choice if he is indeed a player surrogate, but instead shuttles you down a predetermined path.

The game's main plot is tidily written. It fully embraces the fantastical aspects of its story, playing out largely like a mystery/horror with unpredictable twists. The silly, stilted dialogue of Chapter 1 fades away in lieu of genuinely fascinating concepts and characters who are, if a little one-note, still a memorable addition to the worlds you explore.

There are occasional lapses where Victor re-explains something he just told someone in a different interaction, or  where one of his previous actions is mysteriously ignored. For example, at one point you set an angry mob on a character who rages at you for the betrayal; go back in a few minutes and he'll politely welcome you into his home as a friend. In another instance you spend quite a lot of time talking to a group of men who have been searching endlessly for a certain place, often to the point of madness. Once you find it, you can backtrack to talk to them...but there's no way to tell them about what you've found. Little details like this would have made the world so much more convincing.

The ending is certainly not the worst I've seen, but it was too abrupt to emotionally resonate with me. It took maybe ten minutes then boom, game over. After a night of racing to the story's conclusion I was left feeling underwhelmed. (It didn't help that the game crashed right in the middle of the climactic scene.)

TL: DR: The flaws are minor, but there were enough of them to taint my enjoyment of a game that's otherwise beautiful, original, and set in a compelling world. I'd say you should definitely still give it a shot if you like adventure games; just remember it's not a perfect experience.

31903777.review:
Абсолютно уникальная адвенчура, вдохновленная ранними фильмами Романа Полански и Дэвида Кроненберга, окружение в которой сделано из пластилина и картона.

Игра состоит из шести эпизодов, первый из которых вышел еще в конце 2010 года, а последний - в середине мая 2017. В основом, над ней работали всего двое разработчиков из Швеции - Эрик Заринг и Андерс Густаффсон.

Выглядит невероятно круто и необычно в наш цифровой век. Пластилиновая анимация добавляет фантасмагоричности всему происходящему, а с любовью проработанные и руками сделанные декорации придают картинке теплую ламповую идентичность.

В виду ограниченности в финансах, у игры нет озвученных диалогов. Но сами диалоги при этом написаны на отлично. Читая их сразу же получаешь представление о персонажах, и начинаешь погружаться в причудливый мир снов и подсознания, пытаясь побыстрее узнать, чем же закончится история, которая поднимает нетривиальные и серьёзные темы, что в играх встречается крайне редко.

Ещё хочется отметить оригинальные (особенно начиная с середины игры) и при этом логичные (в основном) загадки, которые не затерялись бы в адвенчурах из золотого фонда LucasArts и Sierra. Продолжительность и сложность растет от эпизода к эпизоду, и если первые два проходятся минут за 30, то остальные легко займут по 2-3 часа, т.е. общее игровое время - часов 12-15, что очень хорошо для инди-проекта.

P.S. При прохождении рекомендую почаще сохраняться вручную, т.к. не обошлось без багов. Один раз у меня не отображался текст в книге, а в другой - выбрав не тот вариант ответа в диалоге, потерял возможность поговорить с персонажем снова.

Avventura grafica dallo stile unico, realizzata da due sviluppatori svedesi, che fa del comparto grafico il suo punto di forza.
Non parliamo, infatti, di milioni di poligoni gestiti da un motore grafico di ultimissima generazione, ma di un prodotto realizzato in stop motion utilizzando la plastilina (o simili...) e prodotti di "scarto" o di riciclo.
Il risultato, artisticamente parlando, è meraviglioso.
La storia parte con il freno a mano tirato prendendo, però, velocità man mano che si procede e virando dal quotidiano al fantastico con una transizione ben studiata e senza sembrare troppo forzata.
Gli enigmi sono ben archittetati rimanendo sempre risolvibili utilizzando la logica (non trasversale, per fortuna...).

31846655.review: ¿Alguna vez te has preguntado cómo sería visitar los sueños de otros? En The Dream Machine, puedes y de hecho, debes hacerlo si quieres salvar a los demás y a ti mismo. Con un aspecto visual algo siniestro que quizás en ocasiones recuerden al horror cósmico de Lovecraft, aquí puedes recorrer diversos escenarios que te evocarán la sensación de estar en una entrañable casita de muñecas gracias al mimo puesto en cada uno de sus elementos hechos con materiales cotidianos como palitos de polo, algodón y pequeños objetos del decorado elaborados con arcilla y cartón. Lo más curioso de The Dream Machine es que a pesar de ser digitalizado posteriormente, se ha procurado un gran cuidado en mantener el aspecto y la textura de sus materiales, dejando ver incluso las imperfecciones como las huellas de los dedos en la pintura en los planos más cercanos. Realizado durante 8 años tan solo por dos personas Erik y Anders han sido capaces de construir un precioso mundo en el que una vez dentro, no querrás salir ni para estirar las piernas.

31838142.review:
I've waited a long time to write this review, because for some reason I got it in my head that I wanted to play the entire game before I formed a complete opinion. But now that the game is finished, I realize this was totally unnecessary. The Dream Machine is a god damn masterpiece. And you can tell this from the very beginning. I fell in love after being gifted the first chapters, and went on to immediately buy the next 3, then eagerly waited the final chapter. I was lucky to have come across it towards the end, and only had to wait a year. Others have waited over 8 years for its completion. And the devs (all 2 of them) kept the fans updated through the whole thing. 

It was well worth the wait.

This point n click is fucking gorgeous. The sets blow me away. Every new scene I entered I spent the first few minutes just guessing what everything was made of. I think about how much work it must've taken to put it all together, and its just so impressive. Every chapter gets prettier and prettier. And that final one is just astounding! Some scenes are sweet, and even more are creepy. And I was physically uncomfortable more than a couple times. It was fantastic. Stop motion animation, made with all kinds of stuff like clay, paint, broccoli, pubes. It's really cool. The game looks great. 

And that was just the art! There's even content behind that pretty face! The story was beautiful, and twisted, and at times very sad. It dives deep into a dream world with dark realities and harsh truths. There is no voice acting, you have to read. This is a big plus to me, cuz sometimes bad voice acting can ruin a good story.. But the music and the ambience set a perfect tone, and sculpt ominously soothing voices to imagine as you read. 

As far as gameplay, the interface is very comfortable. Walk speed, and text speeds all adjustable, so you can click through the dialogue at a casual pace. Some puzzles were a bit challenging, but nothing a little more exploring couldn't solve. Many times you can find multiple solutions to a problem, or discover clues that lead you nowhere. But never in an annoying way. I thought exploring was very rewarding. Even when it didn't actually matter. I am told this is called "having fun". I had a lot of fun playing this game. 

I would highly recommend. Don't even wait for a sale, just get it. The devs deserve it. Its probably grossly underpriced anyways considering how much time has gone into it. A serious labor of love. 

Thanks for reading, and THANK YOU DEVS for the awesome experience. Wonderful game!!

31759242.review:
Fantastic visuals, great story, and buggy gameplay concisely sum up The Dream Machine.  An enormous amount of work clearly went in to making this point and click adventure and it pays off thoroughly.  But be warned, save often.

First off, the art is great. It is all hand crafted stop-motion models which are beautifully detail and adds quite a bit of surealness to the experience.  While there are times the animation feels a little sparse, there is never a time were backgrounds feel half done. Every bit of this game has a lot of care put into its visuals.

The story is exceptional, well themed and conceived.  It compares our inanimate selves actively dreaming to the concepts of birth and death.  The story maintains well thought out themes of reverse aging, passiveness vs assertiveness, dreams and freedom. Further, the story goes to very dark places at times. It can be gory, creepy, sexual, blasphemous, incestuous, and even delves fully into abortion. Be aware the darker plotlines are unavoidable so if they are not to your taste, you should avoid this game.

The game play is point and click adventure and it does it very well. Interestingly, there are at times multiple solutions and even small side plots you could optionally visit.  For example at one point you need to fetch some food for a character, different kinds of food can be acquired from different sources and prepared in different ways, all are accepted.  That is a charming bit of extra work that you do not often see in point and click adventures.

But there are some down sides, the game pacing and linearity isn’t consistent.  The first chapter is insanely short, while the last few could take quite a while.  Moreover, some sections of the game play more like a visual novel where you just keep clicking through dialogue; a big part of chapter 6 is like this and it really pulls you out of the game. 

But the biggest failing is the bugs, during my play through the game crashed 8 times with no warning.  The crashes weren’t even repeatable, just random.  Luckily, the auto save is decent enough, but if you hate replaying, save often.  The more disconcerting bug happened when an event was supposed to trigger that would have killed my character but didn’t.  I was left thinking I solved the puzzle, and aimlessly wandered about for quite some time before I realized something was wrong.

So despite the bugs, the game is fantastic. It is dark and creepy, but done in a way that is artful and well balanced with the story and themes. Give this one a try if you are not afraid of story that takes you to places you might not want to think about.

The story in this game has a surprising amount of depth - I often found myself comparing the concepts behind the dream machine to Xenosaga's UMN. Puzzles that have some sort of science in their execution are... well, they're probably more realistic than you expect, I suppose it's best to leave it at that. The art style is distinct, and the visuals are surprisingly polished for such a small development team. (I am, in fact, well into Chapter 4 and still haven't seen anything that seems out of place, as clickable items often do on pre-rendered 2D backdrops.)
There are some spelling mistakes, and possibly less elegant turns of phrase, that detract from the experience, but keep in mind that the developers aren't native English speakers. It's still one of the most enjoyable adventure games I've played recently.

Just one last thing: This game IS NOT FOR KIDS!

El principal atractivo que se espera de este juego es que tanto los escenarios y personajes han sido hechos a mano a base de cartón y de arcilla, lo que le aporta un carácter muy artesanal y una personalidad propia. No obstante, nos encontramos con una aventura gráfica muy amigable, debido a la variedad de diálogo y a la facilidad para desplazarse por el entorno. 
Victor, el protagonista, se mueve a una velocidad punta que se echa de menos en muchas otras aventuras gráficas.
Los puzles son sencillos e intuitivos, pero alguno puede ser de resolución demasiado aleatoria y puedes permanecer atrancado un rato. La banda sonora no está muy allá, y llega a incordiar al rato; pero lo bueno es que se puede desactivar.
El juego está dividido en seis capítulos (en breve saldrá el último) que se pueden adquirir por separado. Mi recomendación es esperar a que esté rebajado para obtenerlo a mitad de precio.

En resumen, un título sencillote para los amantes de los aventuras gráficas y de los juegos con personalidad propia.

Aspectos positivos:

- Escenarios hechos manualmente con cartón y arcilla
- Buena velocidad de movimiento del protagonista
- Buenos diálogos
- Variedad de ajustes en el menú

Aspectos negativos:

- La música puede llegar a hacerse pesada
- Se nota en su desarrollo que es un juego independiente.
- Puedes quedarte atrancado en algún momento sin saber qué hacer.

30307194.review:
I guess we have all experienced it: starting a game we have bought in the spur of a moment during a summer sale, maybe along with a dozen others that turned out half-okay, half-not-so-okay, smugly thinking to ourself, "Well, let’s get this over with, shall we?" - only to find ourself blown away and feeling like a whole new person two nights later, albeit one that needs a shower and some fresh air. Like when you start watching Doctor Who because you have nothing else to do and end up building full-scale TARDISes for your cats, knocking four times every darn time before entering a room and telling your friends how much you’ve grown as a person watching it. But to be honest, no point and click adventure game has done this to me in quite the epic scale as The Dream Machine has. And having grown up with an older sibling with access to Leisure Suit Larry and Monkey Island, that is saying something.

So after half-heartedly convincing myself to try it, I almost startled a bit when I found myself laughing at the introduction to chapter 1. I mean an authentic laugh, not the face people make while typing “lol”. The game continued to surprise me with what unfolded to be an incredibly beautifully made little world full of amazing detail and a unique artistic style. And while it was cozy within its little walls, with its jazz and ambient music, I found it to be packed with possibilities for exploration.

So the playdoh-dollhouse really brought the childhood memories on their way. But what really gave me that sense of "this feels like the first time I've ever played a PC game" and “this is the way I actually see things when I don’t think about it too much”, was how well the shape and sound of the game were complemented with its storytelling and dialogues. The dialogues, because they showed a truthful yet non-judging and loving understanding of human nature. And the storytelling, because it managed to remain relaxing and innocent throughout the game while at the same time consistently mounting in suspense and surrealism. And in more than one instance one has to flatout admire the way it shows things in such a truthful manner that is rare in computer games: that people sometimes do things that seem dark and morbid, but then they are genuinely sorry and apologize; or that the elderly lady from next door with her teapots and doileys at some point of her life did have a sex life, such as it was.

The makers of The Dream Machine have taken all those little impressions of life that are usually limited to be experienced in the privacy of our heads, and shaped them into something that can be shared - not as a clever book on psychology, but as a wonderfully made game everyone can enjoy. To me, this is what makes The Dream Machine so amazing, and if it does turn out that the makers want to publish the game’s script as a clever book after all, I will totally buy it.

This entire series is simply incredible. Frustrated as I was through the later chapters, there is no question this this game deserves many accolades and praises.

The story and art traverses so many aspects of thought and expectations. The whole concept of how people portray themselves in their mind verus how they do so in the physical world bares much investigation. There's also a lot said about voyuerism. The main statement might be that more people are looking into each other's lives than we like to think.

Every scene is carefully crafted with love and attention. The dialogue is witty and hilarious. The mask-like faces of the characters gives them an oddly drab and somewhat spooky kind of roteness to their every action, thought and movement. The puppet aspect of the characters really provides a lot of layers to think about.

You should get the whole package because you'll really want Chapter 6 once it's ready. Again, prepare to be very frustrated and more than likely consult YouTube videos for guidance. Hopefully you won't have to too much. Most solutions are pretty intuitive and you can find out based on the environment.

29434449.review: This was one of many games I bought during a Steam summer sale and can I say how glad I am that I did? It's challenging, but not impossibly so, quirky with a delicious dark undertone, funny in all the right places, and full of things you never knew you wanted to see. From a ship poulated by a dozen versions of you to an apartment where time and space are determined by the photographs you find and rearrange within it, each new dream is like a whole new experience, with different and unique characters, new locations that are a feast for the eyes, and new puzzles and mechanics that keep that classic point n click gameplay feeling fresh and new. There's so much more I could rave about but I guess it's one of those things where I gotta say "you just HAVE to try it!" I just gotta find out how to give the developers more of my money since I got it on sale! Can't wait for Chapter 6!!

Given the dream focus of the narrative, there's a certain amount of Pschonauts to the logic and humour, and I had a few Monkey Island moments with some of the puzzles.

There are some frustrating elements to the game. Every line of dialogue requires a click to get passed, but the last line will normally register the click on the environment, so you'll end up interacting with something else.
Walking can be frustratingly slow, especially with the lag on certain screens.
Some puzzles were quite vague and required a lot of walking around to solve, but overall it was satisfying to work them out in the end.

28423459.review:
制作非常精美的一款游戏，用的是泥塑动画的表现形式。搬入新家的维克多先生发现卧室壁画后面被安装了色相头，气愤的他来找公寓拥有者兼管理员菲力克斯理论，原来菲力克斯家族4代都在公寓的地下室研究人类的梦境，并成功造出一台机器，可以将自己的意识投射到别人的梦境中去。然而进化到现在的机器已经不再受人控制，它在梦境中将菲力克斯处死。为了拯救自己的妻子和公寓里的其他人，维克多必须潜入他们形形色色的梦境中去，找出机器的化身将其消灭。
游戏谜题的难度属于中上等，不过谜题的素质很高，不会有牵强附会之感。第一章最后有一块电路板，需要你把电路中各个开关转到合适的方向，从而避开所有电阻，让电路短路，才能打开机关，我觉得这个挺好玩的。第二章里听不清你说什么的石像，你需要在他耳朵里放上东西，但是你不知道要放什么，顺序怎么样。其实这个是要你去模仿人耳中耳的听骨链，顺序是锤骨、砧骨、镫骨，对应的物品是锤子、铁砧、马镫。所以这些谜题需要你自己善于观察、好的逻辑思维能力和足够大的脑洞。

27900359.review:
I generally tend not to review games, since I'm rather poor at expressing how much I enjoy them unless I go on for too long with many tangents. I'll try to keep this brief while still getting my point across.

The Dream Machine, with all its current chapters is simply one of the most creative, underrated gaming experiences I've had well... ever (at risk of sounding like a suck up to the game's developers or something). It's got a pretty original plot considering the heavily-explored topic of dreams and entering dreams. You play as Victor, who just moved into a new apartment with his pregnant wife, only to find out a series of dark secrets leading up to Victor essentially having the fate of humanity in his hands.

The game's possibly most wonderful part is its aesthetic, with painstakingly-made sets made of clay, cardboard, and other such materials and a nice, dark soundtrack to enhance the atmosphere of the world further. While again avoiding spoilers, I'll say that the settings, especially in the various dreams, present varying, beautiful environments that all take full advantage of the ability to highlight the psychological state of the person having said dream. I feel like I'll spoil something if I say too much, but I'll probably have to get back to fixing this review a bit more with more reasons to buy it. It's a delightful game overall and I reccomend it wholeheartedly! Definitely my pick for the Steam awards "I played it before it won an award" award, due to its shockingly-underrated nature.

As an edit, playing the final chapter was riveting. One of my only problems with it was that Vincent seemed to grow to accepting of all the weirdness happening around him, but then I realized that it was more or less exasperation at the fact that he's been dealing with reality-bending and harrowing stuff for days (no spoilers, but he experiences and witnesses some violent or deadly things), and it would only make sense for him to essentially say "Okay, this is happening now." I refuse to spoil anything that happens, but it takes FULL advantage of how weird dreams can get and takes every last opportunity to show how the Dream Machine is trying to impede Vincent on his journey. And the ending... that ending was amazing. I, again, refuse to spoil anything, but I still strongly reccomend this game to anyone who likes the art, point and click gameplay, or even just story driven stuff. People who appreciate any artistic aspect of gaming as a creative medium are going to find at least something to love about this, and I still definitely reccomend this underrated goodness very highly!

27868205.review: The “I Thought This Game Was Cool Before It Won An Award” Award

27822652.review:
Just add this to the list of things that prove that video games are art.

This game has some of the most intriguing, gorgeous, adorable (and in many instances disgusting) designs ever contructed.  The art style is like if the film "Mirror Mask" were made into a game.  And the plot is just as gorgeous and surreal.  "The Dream Machine" is like the ultimate indie game.  

You play as Victor Neff, a self-proclaimed "handsome" man, who has just moved into a strange new flat with his pregnant wife, but things get strange very quickly when your wife notices the landlord acting really weird.  I will not spoil any of the plot.  It is a game you must see to believe, but if you can believe it, there is in fact a Dream Machine in the game.

Many players who have received this game negatively because of the short nature of the first two chapters (which can potentially both be completed in under two hours combined) are wrong in assuming because of this, the whole game is very short.  It is not, in fact.  By chapter 3, the length of each chapter exceeds 2 hours (the fifth chapter took over 3 (almost 4) hours to complete as was by-far the longest and most complex).  And yes, each chapter's puzzles are more intricate and complex, making the difficulty just right for players who need to adjust to the weirdness levels this game pushes out. And also remember, a short game is not a bad game.  There are point-and-click adventure games that can be beaten entirely within a half-hour, but they are brilliant.  So if you find yourself getting through "The Dream Machine" very quickly, do not equate that with it being a bad game.

The first two chapters are there to get the player's feet wet with how this game is going to present itself.  It's really surrealistic, thus it needs to demonstrate how the puzzles are going to work and the imaginitive ways to solve them.  (Hopefully, without spoiling much, I will give you an example.  In Chapter 2, there is a character that you have to talk to but he doesn't speak clearly at all.  The problem is one of his vocal cords is bent. The solution is to remove the cord and bang it with a hammer until it is straightened. Then the character will speak clearly).  Hopefully that was a good example of how unconventional the puzzles are in the game.

And the puzzles are very well implimented.  There were times, however, when it is so unclear what to do, clicking everything on everything becomes a method to get through the game.  I only found this problem on Chapter 5 (which was a huge chapter with a lot of map screens).  The level was much darker than the others making it a bit difficult to see items that needed to be picked up and characters were not clear in what they needed from Victor making it difficult to understand what to do, though I do know the developers are still updating the game very regularly fixing this and that, so the problems with Chapter 5 may very well be fixed in a couple of months.

The atmosphere in the game is brilliant, with a slow build to the weirder things (the ending of Chapter 5 was by far the strangest thing) with subtle music and an even mixture of a serious tone from the characters mixed with a humourous tone.  There were two parts that had me laughing out loud: a part with these pumpkins, and a part with a knight in armour.

The artwork of the game is something to behold.  Looking at each screen on the game and noticing the tiny details the developers put in give the game an extra dose of appreciation.  They clearly care about this game (especially since it's been in development for almost a decade).  Regardless of people disliking the game because they think it's grotesque, I think it's beautiful and I truly wish there were more games (let alone stop-motion films) in this style.

27640703.review:
Original, un vrai travail d'artiste pour les décors et les personnages, un petit jeu indépendant fait avec amour et passion. Si l'on peut être surpris au début, on se laisse rapidement absorber par l'histoire et l'atmosphère.

Les 2 premiers chapitres sont plutôt courts et les enigmes se résolvent plutôt rapidement. On retrouve ici tous les outils des jeux d'aventures classiques (inventaire, puzzles, objets, dialogues, indices...). N'aimant pas les jeux "en morceaux", j'ai acquis l'ensemble des 5 Chapitres et je vais donc les tester dans la foulée.

Les chapitres suivant donnenet vraiment de l'ampleur au jeu car ils semblent être encore plus aboutis. 

Malgré une aire de jeu plutôt réduite, le Chapitre 3 est plus long que les deux précédents réunis. Le jeu prend un plus plus d'ampleur notamment avec la multiplication des personnages et donc des dialogues. L'atmosphere est intrigante et même dérangeante à la fin.

Le chapitre 4 est de bonne facture, peut être même plus difficile que les autres car comme on est pas vraiment guidé c'est à nous de bien interprêter les indices que l'on trouve (ou peut être suis-je un peu lent à comprendre) et de faire des tentatives pour comprendre les possibilités qui s'offrent à nous. L'histoire se poursuis et le passage dans le rêve fait même un peu froid dans le dos, c'est presque gênant d'observer ce qui s'y passe.

Dans le Chapitre 5 les développeurs arrivent encore à pousser un peu plus loin leur maitrise : plus long, plus varié, toujours aussi bien fait... L'intrigue est prenante et l'ensemble est même d'une bonne difficultée. Il est clair que l'on peut attendre le dernier round avec impatience. Bravo.

Pris dans son ensemble c'est véritablement un très bon jeu d'aventure pour peu que l'on s'immerge dans l'univers proposé. il ne faut pas se laisser berner par la simplicité et la bonhomie du début, le jeu évolue au fil des chapitres en terme d'ambiance et de casse-têtes.

Le jeu n'est pas en Français et il y a pas mal de dialogues (sous forme de textes, pas d'audio), pour ceux qui ont du mal avec la langue de Shakespeare, passez votre chemin pour l'instant.

26626958.review:
At the time I write this review I am partway through Chapter 5 (edit for finished game at end).

This game will frustrate the hell out of you, but it's so worth it.

Like many of these kinds of games it has puzzles that don't seem to make sense, and "clues" that don't really tell you anything. You will get stuck when you think you've tried everything, and even turning "hint mode" on won't be enough (as the "hints" it gives you are practically useless). 

There are still a few things that need to be fixed, for example full-screen mode oftens crashes or runs slowly so I haven't been playing full-screen. Because of this I've sometimes missed clues as I just can't see them very well on the small screen! And for a game that's so visually impressive it's a shame I can't appreciate it fully by having my screen covered with it.

I still recommend, as the visuals are SO interesting and beautiful (and creepy!!). Without being a full-on horror game you will still feel weird and eerie playing this, you don't need jump scares because the atmosphere is enough. It really is full of dream-like imagination.

I can't wait to see how this all wraps up!

Update: I've now finished the game, and I still agree with everything said earlier and thoroughly recommend it. I was a bit disappointed with the gameplay and art of the last chapter as it felt a bit repetitive, but it didn't make me not want to play! I could tell there must be multiple endings because leading up to the end I kept thinking "this feels wrong, there must be an alternative but I can't figure out what it is..." and I got a pretty shitty ending. Normally this would make me feel annoyed after wasting time on the game, but I'm actually pretty excited to re-visit the whole game and see if I can get a different ending next time.

Im Humble vor etlicher Zeit erstanden und nu den Key wiedergefunden.

Es ist durchgehend auf Englisch, aber bisher in einem recht einfachen Stil, sodass es auch für weniger Bewanderte leicht zu verstehen sein sollte. Die Atmosphäre ist magisch bis düster, also nichts für Sommerlaune, sondern eher was für verregnete Herbsttage. Ich freue mich sehr, dass ich nun bei den immer kälter werdenen Temperaturen mit einer warmen Tasse Kakao in diese Welt abtauchen und im Soundtrack versinken kann, denn genau dafür ist dieses Spiel da! nach ner halben Stunde im Spiel hatte ich sofort das Gefühl, mir würde jemand in einer großen Heimbibliothek aus dem Ohrensessel vorm Kamin eine Geschichte erzählen.

26470835.review: Het spel begint als een vrij doorsnee 'point & click adventure', maar dan met klei/papier/karton animatie. Mijn eerste indruk was niet al te positief, de eerste puzzels waren erg makkelijk en de animatie zag er wat simplistisch uit. Maar toen ik verder kwam in het spel, merkte ik dat het verhaal me steeds meer vastgreep. De kwaliteit van de animaties verbeterde ook iets en de omgevingen en de puzzels werden steeds interessanter. Bij sommige spellen zie je dat de start van het spel heel interessant is, maar dat de makers vervolgens geen inspiratie hadden en de kwaliteit van het verhaal en de puzzels inzakken. Hier is het precies andersom, hoe verder het verhaal komt, hoe creatiever het verhaal en de puzzels worden. Niet voor niets hebben ze eerder een episode in tweeën moeten knippen en is er een extra hoofdstuk toegevoegd. Kortom, laat je niet afschrikken door de eerste 30-60 minuten van het spel, maar zet door, want zodra je de droommachine (dream machine) ontdekt, wordt het spel in rap tempo steeds beter.

Шикарно. Давно не встречала таких интересных игр. Практически без недостатков - ни тебе затянутого сюжета, ни скучных диалогов. Отличное звуковое сопровождение, начиная от звуков, заканчивая музыкой. А происходит там ну очччень интересное, не оторваться. Игра длииинная, что радует. По сюжету и его реализации, а также воплощению всего этого в физической форме - я такого точно не встречала за 20 лет своей квестовой практики.

9 баллов из 10 (-1 за некоторую тормознутость ГГ)

P.S. Уберите детей, беременных и животных со слабой психикой от монитора во время прохождения

26201559.review:
This is the best point & click game in my life. After finishing the game, I was still so obsessed with it that I made every of my friends play it, while I sit behind and watch them playing, and now I'm still obsessed with it.

[b][u]What I like the most about this game:[/u][/b]

[b]Story:[/b]
The story is interesting and has some plot twist, keeping us curious about what will happen next. And if chapter 1 & 2 aren't good enough, the next chapters will probably keep you playing this game. Back then, when I finished chapter 3 and need to wait for other chapters, I was afraid that chapter 3 is too good, and that I would be disappointed when chapter 4 released, but in the end, I wasn't: Chapter 3 is already really good, but chapter 4 is better, and chapter 5 is even better than chapter 4.

[b]Puzzle:[/b]
The puzzle isn't too hard and is logical, well sometimes it becomes really difficult, but totally makes sense.
Some people complaining that sometimes you can't examine an object until a NPC told you to do it, but to me, that's what make the puzzle better: You need to actually read and understand what's going on in order to process, blindly clicking around won't get you anywhere.

[b]Atmosphere:[/b]
It isn't a horror game, but somehow it gives you the chills, I always like that part of any story.

[b]Dialogue:[/b]
Due to the fact that there isn't any voice actor, the dialogues won't fade away unless you click on game screen. It's great for someone who isn't good at English like me since I can't read English really fast, on this game I can slowly read and understand every bit of what the characters are saying.

[b][u]What I don't like about this game:[/u][/b]
Chapter 6. If you think chapter 3, 4, 5 are good and feeling so hyped about the next chapter, prepare to be disappointed. Unlike chapter 5, chapter 6 is very short and leave many unanswered questions. The ending isn't satisfied as well, but maybe it's just my opinion.

Chapter 6 ruined my wonderful experience on this game, but beside that, everything of this game is perfect, so I would still recommend this game, and yes, it's still my best point & click game ever.
