25120996.review:
This is a great traditional-style point-and-click game with lovely (although a little odd) characters and background rendered in paper and clay. I found the story enthralling and the gameplay challenging, but not impossible - most of it is based in logic (as well as a little old-school point-and-click logic!).

The atmosphere and storytelling was atmosphetic, the characters stood out, and the fact it looks great and the interface is easy to use (and mistakes cannot be easily made, unlike with some games) made is so easy and fluid to play. The story is based around an interesting combination of ideas on dreams, philosophy and a little danger from basic-level AI thrown in for good measure. The puzzles are excellent and logical, and I found that with enough thought, pretty much all of them can be solved without too much stress.

I certainly found it quite addictive, and although stuck on a couple of puzzles, I got through it relatively unscathed - and it was a lot of fun to work the puzzles out; they gave quite the sense of achievement!

This is highly recommended (in fact, it was actually a very enthusiastic recommendation to me) to point-and-click enthusiasts, puzzlers, and anyone who wants to try something with deep atmostphere, great characters, and an intresting, entertaining story. It also helps that it looks pretty great too!

After playing Ch. 1 + 2, I'll certainly be getting Chapters 3-6 now for certain!

25062870.review:
TLDR: Whoever made this game deeply and truly loves the point-and-click adventure game genre. 

I bought this game with horribly mediocre expectations in mind, and I could not have been more incorrect.  

Truly immersive, gripping plot escapes a lot of the newer point-and-click adventure games, which consequently makes them forgettable; the ideas, while solid in concept, lack some of the critical components of cohesion that made the early point-and-clicks so personally endearing.  (e.g.:) Missing sensible characters, correct choices don’t align with player’s intuitive thinking on the problem, game lacks the atmospheric depth and detail that make it immersive, and they often include overreaching or predictable plot elements that fall somewhat flat when played. 

This game dodges those pitfalls like a champ.  The storyline is novel-worthy - the immersion, tone, and general charisma of the game are superlative, while managing to strike a delicate balance between elements of adventure, horror and comedy. The (very) innovative and well-executed use of claymation lent profoundly to the overall ambiance and tone of the game. 

Well-tailored, organic dialogue coupled with a streamlined and easy-to-use interface make the gameplay seamless.  Normally trading action buttons for a one-click method can trivialize the puzzles or can make the puzzles almost too abstract in an attempt to provide some challenge, but this (pleasantly) was not the case.  The developers tuned and paced the game well by balancing the simpler puzzles with more conceptually challenging ones, to the extent that brute force never feels like the only viable tool in solving the problem at hand. 

I don’t like to compare the newer adventure games to the genre-defining point-and-clicks of the 90’s, but in terms of the game’s ability to engage and captivate you as the player, it’s secured a spot in my personal hall of fame next to games like King's Quest, Monkey Island, and Day of the Tentacle.  I can’t wait for Chapter 6.

Fascinating and bizarre, clever and logical, entertaining, varied and original. Well done.

+
-Story and style is original and different. The clay models give a unique (estranged; distancing yet familar) atmosphere and feel to the game. Some content can be disturbing for some. Story is interesting - some crazy stuff here! :D
-Puzzle variation. Some puzzles are quite easy while others are more tricky. Occasionally, a bit of luck is required to solve puzzles (one puzzle in particular, but won't spoil it), but most can be solved by revisiting places, experimenting and thinking things through. Different puzzles require different approaches, but hints can be found if you're awake.
-Hotkeys for fullscreen/windowed mode, sound off/on, etc. Convenient and useful if you take breaks (as you can see by my hours!), etc.

-
-Voices could have improved the game, though I read and clicked quickly through most dialogue anyway. Still, There are some weird characters and lines. Voices could be fun.
-Increasing walking speed would help! There is a fair amount of walking around, and Victor is really not in a hurry.
-A few times the game glitched and certain functions were broken. Fixed when reloaded or sometimes estarted game. For the most part, though, not a problem.

Looking forward to chapter 6.

23336050.review:
Crafted from clay and ingenuity, The Dream Machine is a point-and-click adventure through the mind. The world - or worlds as it quickly becomes - presented here is undeniably stunning, though the misshapen forms of its people and the engrossing plot at hand distract from that beauty. This is a game that demands that the urgency of the plot be forgotten from time to time in favor of stopping to take in the sights. However the novelty of its art style isn\'t the only thing The Dream Machine has to offer. Some of its puzzles are absolutely brilliant and though a few did seem to come out of left field, none felt absurd or out of place. A single mouse button takes care of all player actions making the controls very accessible, but also equally restrictive. Frustration is often born of not having enough tools to come up with a variety of possible solutions or to tell the game what you would like to do, and this is a hole The Dream Machine tends to fall into. 
The game is very much a work in progress. It\'s still somewhat buggy and is missing its concluding chapter, but it is very playable even without those finishing touches. The individual chapters are a bit short, but they are priced to their playtime, so it\'s hard to complain about that. Having played five out of the the six intended chapters, the story so far is satisfying, as is each chapter taken on its own, even if it\'s all currently ended with a cliffhanger.

21350424.review:
I have over 600 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game. 

One Hour Reviews #50 - The Dream Machine

Before I started my series of reviews, I hadn't really played much in the way of adventure games.  But, it's been nice seeing a resurgence in this genre, and now I've had the opportunity to play through several adventure games.

Going in, I didn't know anything about The Dream Machine.  So playing it felt a little like going to a movie that you didn't see the trailer for, and you don't even know what genre of movie it is.   And I'm glad I did that because I feel like I've just watched the opening act of a mystery, so not knowing anything ahead of time definitely added to that sense of mystery.

I won't spoil anything about the story, other than to say I enjoyed the first chapter, which I just had time to finish in my first hour of play.  The story kept me engaged enough that by the time I noticed the time my playthough was nearly over.  I think this is one of the better compliments you can give a game when it has that ability to suck you in.

The actual gameplay itself seems fairly typical for a point and click adventure game.  It involves a lot of walking around, doing some pixel hunting to find points of interest, and picking up things that you'll need to use later.  Pretty much everything I could pick up I ended up using on something, and often in ways I would not have expected.  Besides the "use this item on this thing" type of puzzle, I also played a different kind of puzzle that involved turning knobs on a machine.

I did occasionally have some trouble lining up my mouse cursor on the right pixel to pick something up, but it didn't happen often enough to be really annoying.  Also, when you move the mouse to the top of the screen, a bar will pop down with your inventory, but sometimes this interferes with you trying to point to something at the top of the screen.  Other than these couple of minor annoyances, I didn't really run into any problems with the game.

Besides the story, I also enjoyed the art style.  Most of the adventure games I've played have an animated, cartoon like art style.  But this game has a claymation inspired art style which really sets it apart.  I can really tell a lot of work went into the art for this game.  The characters look great, and so do the backgrounds.  Everything has this hand crafted look to it.

I'm not sure if the following chapters are any longer to play, but I could see some potential concern about the game being relatively short (for what you pay for it).  There are 6 chapters total (but the 6th is not out yet).   I wouldn't be surprised if the follow on chapters take a little longer than an hour to get through.  For me personally it's not an issue, as I think the game is worth the price, and would happily recommend it.

20841084.review:
Note: This review is only for Chapters 1-5 so far (haven't finished 6 yet). 

This game was collecting dust in my library for quite a while. I figured it was just another standard P&C to slog through when I had nothing better to do. On a whim I started playing though, and boy, was I wrong.

I don't think I've been this impressed by a P&C in a very long time. It has its flaws of course, but I can unwaveringly and wholeheartedly recommend it to any lover of P&C puzzle games, especially experienced players looking for more thoughtful challenges (some of which put even Daedalic's better puzzles to shame). 

If you're already intrigued, do buy and play this game. If you're still on the fence or want to know more of what you're getting yourself into, keep reading. Skip to the end for a sum-up.

[h1]The Good Stuff[/h1]
[b]General Format[/b]
From the very start, [i]The Dream Machine[/i] sharply breaks from the by-now-expected P&C conventions: long cut-scene intros, expositional voice-overs, difficulty modes, Captain Obvious tutorials, sparkly "active zones/items", and recharging hint systems will not be found here. (There's a vague "hint mode", but it's off by default.) There is no hand-holding. You are thrown directly into the water (somewhat literally) and expected to figure it out for yourself. Yes, the first short section does function a little like a tutorial, but it's still one you must navigate on your own. While this kind of no-HUD, no-hints style may seem potentially difficult or off-putting to some people, it's actually nice to see a game that doesn't patronize the player. In other words, it "speaks to you like an adult", and duly expects you to think like one. That's incredibly refreshing.

It also does not follow the cliché format of "random female protagonist solving a mystery she's only vaguely connected with". I'm all for female protagonists, but it's still nice to see variety once in a while, as well as a protagonist more invested in their own storyline. 

[b]Presentation/Style[/b]
I've always loved games that take advantage of more unique graphic styles, particularly stop-motion. In this case, some aspects of the clay and cardboard style take a bit of getting used to (the characters don't really have facial expressions, for example, or even eyeballs), but it still creates a very pleasant and memorable feel. Anyone out there who remembers the 1996 game "The Neverhood" will definitely notice a similar charm. A more contemporary example would be something like [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/421880/]Plastiland[/url]. There are no animated sequences or cut-scenes breaking up the flow or art style, like you'll find in a lot of modern games. Clay and cardboard is the omnipresent playing field, and apart from a couple of longer dialogues to click through, the player has control of the protagonist from start to finish - even while transitioning from one chapter to the next.

[b]Storyline[/b]
This has to be one of the most in-depth and convoluted (in a good way) storylines I've encountered in a P&C in years. Physically delving into the "collective unconscious" or "dreamscape" is not a new idea, but the [i]reasons[/i] you venture through them are unique. In addition, the decisions Victor is presented with throughout, whether straightforward, questionable, or bizarre, are ultimately what shape his character and slowly allow the player to sympathize with his personal situation. Victor/the player has very clear emotional and realistic reasons for being proactive in the story, as opposed to the passive "outsider" feeling one gets from games with a nonchalant and uninvolved protagonist. 

Victor and the other characters may not be very deep as far as personality, but interactions are scripted quite well, essentially turning each character into an archetype anyone can relate to - which is significant, considering the lack of facial expressions.

I was also impressed with the number of times situations or aspects of the story genuinely shocked or touched me. Without giving anything away, the slow realization that occurs at the end of Chapter 5 literally made me gasp. That level of emotional immersion is very rare in my experience.

[b]Puzzles[/b]
The puzzles are where [i]Dream Machine[/i] sets itself apart. They involve in-depth thinking and down-to-earth, "realistic" logic, instead of "try every item in your inventory and hope something works". One of the better initial examples that illustrate that stark difference is the second puzzle involving the hammer and anvil. Yes, it requires a bit of real-world knowledge, but the sense of accomplishment once you pick up on that is extremely satisfying. Some puzzles (like the hammer one) have an obscure hint within the dialogue to point you in the right direction, but most of the time solutions simply require exploration of the environment and good 'ol brain grease. Young Edie's advice in Chapter 4 is a particularly tricky dialogue hint, but pretty darn clever in the end. Another example of "realistic" thinking involves the second cube in Willard's dream in Chapter 5. It's such a simple solution, but players these days are so accustomed to [i]over[/i]thinking puzzles that it's easy to miss the obvious round-peg-goes-in-round-hole stuff.

[b]Length[/b]
Each chapter takes a good amount of time to complete. Even taking idling into account, it took me over 9-10 hours to complete all 5 chapters, which is really good compared to the 2.5 to 3 hours you can squeeze out of many cookie-cutter P&Cs. It's more on par with the length of the better Daedalic games, like The Whispered World or The Dark Eye series.

[h1]The Not So Good Stuff[/h1]
My main gripe is with a handful of puzzles. Their common aspect is that you must return to a specific location you previously visited at least once, because something there will have changed that significantly furthers the gameplay (a visual cue or new interactive object), but you are given no indication that you need to revisit that location. You're left to randomly search areas and play "spot the difference" from memory. That isn't fun. One of the worst offenders is [spoiler]the near-unreadable cipher that appears in the front office[/spoiler] after you complete Morton's chapter. Solving that puzzle also requires knowledge about another room you probably forgot about, because you used it once already. It's a lot of needless running around unless you keep notes. And don't even get me started on the recipe book and door code in Chapter 3. Clever mechanics, yes, but waay too obscure. I don't like resorting to LPs when the rest of the game is so satisfying to solve on my own. (Note that following a walkthrough can spoil a lot of the "surprise/realization" aspects of the story, so a decent amount of patience for the majority of puzzles is recommended.)

The fusebox puzzle in the apartment was also one I had to look up. I may be in a minority here, but that wire layout made no sense to me (and I've played many similar puzzles before).

For such a polished game, it was a tad strange to see some obvious spelling errors. But they don't disrupt gameplay/immersion.

[h1]Overall[/h1]
[i]The Dream Machine[/i] is leagues above its competitors in the genre as far as depth of story and intelligent puzzle design. Solutions are smart, realistic/logical, and very satisfying to figure out. A few puzzles are [i]too[/i] obscure or provide few/no clues for progression, but as annoying as those can be in the moment, they don't detract from the quality of the game as a whole. 

As a seasoned P&C player, I wholly recommend this title to anyone looking for more intellectual challenge from a clever game that not only does not hand-hold, but treats the player like the smart person they are instead of assuming they need a tutorial on how to pick up a shovel.

19637548.review:
Dream Machine  - квест, который ещё раз доказывает, что удачная концепция игры - это хорошо, но развивающаяся концепция - гораздо лучше. Разбивка на эпизоды здесь действительно оправдана: каждый из них это одновременно и отдельная история, снабжённая собственными локациями, и часть общего сюжета. Мир глины и картона, снабжённый приятной анимацией, действительно поражает (представленное в трейлере и на скриншотах - лишь скромное начало).
 Но самое главное, что разработчики ни на минуту не забывают, что делают квест, а не а простую инсталляцию. И здесь радует путь, выбранный авторами - обоснованность и логичность. Чувствуется завершённость каждой загадки, при этом ответ во многом находится интуитивно (но не всегда легко). Сюжет спойлерить не хочется, поэтому скажем так: это знакомая (хотя и нечасто используемая) история с весьма оригинальным подходом, заключённая во множество событий, диалогов и даже литературы. 
 Как итог: Dream Machine - это один из наиболее "цельных" квестов, в который мне доводилось играть и единственная игра, после прохождения которой я первым делом полез искать историю разработки. О, господи, 10/10 и бутылку рома создателям.

19601529.review: Loved it! Best experience I've had with a point-and-click adventure since the 90's - the sense of mystery and exploration, puzzle-solving and the sheer visual impression was awesome! Some weird performance stuff, but I tried this on a 6 year old office laptop so what can you expect? If you think the trailer looks good, this is worth it!

19472795.review: Probably my favorite point and click of all time.  It's one thing to have hand drawn art in a point and click, but it's another to have these beautifully crafted real-life hand built scenes.  There is detail in there all the way to 1920x1080 (maybe more?) and truly a pleasure to look at.  Also, the puzzles all make sense and at no point do you "rub every item in your inventory on every interactable object" like you end up doing in some adventure games.  The story is genuinely interesting and isn't just silly, overblown, and played for gags like many other adventure games (not that that's a bad thing, just that since many other games do that it's nice to see something different).  The tutorial segment is extremely cleverly put together and really sets the tone for the whole game.  The puzzles are unique, interesting, and most importantly seamlessly integrate into the world instead of feeling a bit forced and unrelated to the world like other adventure games do (yet another towers of hanoi mini-game anyone?).

19450075.review:
First off all: Do you know how trailers play up games and make it seem like it's going be awesome, and then it sort of sucks?
This game is the opposite. The trailer is underwhelming, the game itself is fucking incredible. The music, art design, writing, and creativity of this point-and-click, is just lovely. It doesn't get enough publicity, and every chance I get I recommend this game to people.
Aside from slight glitches in the game at times, I don't really have anything to complain about with this game. The puzzles are really unique and satisfying, the music is haunting and ambient, and the character design is creepy, but seriously grows on you. I really love Victor as a character. But if you really need a reason to play this game other than the fact that it's engrossing and downright beautiful, then just know you can be the king of some talking pumpkins.

19110752.review:
I'll start this review by saying that I've only played the first four chapters of this game thus far...that's four outta six, and the sixth isn't even done yet, but having completed two-thirds surely earns me my two cents.  Secondly, and simply, I'll just say that this is absolutely, positively, hands-down one of the best point-and-click games that will ever be made, probably in the annals of human history, and unless the devs drop dead in the meantime you can rest at least 99% assured that they WILL finish the darned thing, even if they're taking a bit longer than they initially intended to.  

   But hey, which would you prefer...a really, really good point-and-click game a year ago, or a truly classic point-and-click game in, say, a couple of years from now?  Cockroach Inc ain't dumb...they're in this one for the history books and the betterment of mankind, nuthin' less.  And you'd better BELIEVE it, buddy-boy.
  
   Point-and-click games and myself, we don't exactly have a history of getting along that well, but this may well emerge as my all-time personal favourite of the genre.  Sure, I've required a few walkthrough consultations to date, but such is be expected with a semi-vegetative brain such as mine.  Whatever you do, don't go holding my confirmed stoopidity against the game, a'ight?  I'm the idiot, it's the savant.  Clever mother-fuckers, them Cockroaches...
 
Verdict: 9.5/10.
 
(PS How many games reference - whether deliberately or inadvertently - the sheer brilliance that is David Cronenberg's VIDEODROME?  Maybe a bit of EXistenZ thrown in for good measure?!  Talk about taste!!  Gorgeous fucking claymation, too, I might add...)

The Dream Machine - Chapter 1&2: 
-: herná doba, slabší začiatok prvej kapitoly, rozdelenie na kapitoly, chýbajúci dabing, animácie postáv, audio, cena

+: grafika, dizajn, príbeh, hudba, hlavolamy, atmosféra v druhej kapitole, zábava, postavy, lokácie, rozdelenie na kapitoly, cena

Verdikt: Victor Neff spolu so svojou ženou sa práve nasťahoval do nového bytu. Po chvíli však zistia, že to nebude tak obyčajný obytný dom s obyčajnými susedmi. Prvá kapitola hry The Dream Machine slúži na rýchle osvojenie si základných herných mechanizmov a uvedenie do deja. Všeobecne ju možno označiť za slabšiu, no hráča dokáže uviesť do deja. Druhá kapitola sa týka predovšetkým tajuplného stroja, jeho vlastníka, čiže Victorovho suseda a jeho sna. Druhá kapitola je po príbehovej stránke oveľa lepšia ako tá prvá. Možno ju označiť až za mysterióznu vďaka náplni a zaujímavým hlavolamom s esenciou filozofickým myšlienok. Celkovo prvé dve kapitoly hry The Dream Machine sú zaujímavé a ich obsah ocenia predovšetkým priaznivci nenásilných adventúr.

84%

The Dream Machine:
-: herná doba, riešenie niektorých hlavolamov, rozdelenie na kapitoly, chýbajúci dabing, slabšie animácie, niektoré lokality, audio

+: grafika, príbeh, dizajn, hudba, puzzle, atmosféra, zábava, lokácie, postavy, sny, rozdelenie na kapitoly, cena

Verdikt: Poznáte to... ráno sa zobudíte pod stanom podporeným polotoporom, že si ani nemôžete uľaviť na toalete. A keď to konečne povolí, začnete premýšľať na tým, čo sa vám snívalo počas spánku. Podľa hry The Dream Machine netreba brať sny ľahkovážne a to hlavne ak po jednom z nich nájdete kameru vo svojej spálni a podivný stroj u suseda. Po slabšom začiatku nasleduje spád a zamotávanie sa do snového chaosu podivných udalostí. Pozitívom a súčasne negatívom hry je jej rozdelenie na kapitoly. Ak vás prvé dve zaujmú, je potrebné si kúpiť aj zvyšné, no ak nie, ušetríte peniaze. Každá z kapitol je niečim charakteristická a zábavná. Záleží na postave, jej mysli alebo sne, v ktorom sa odohráva dej. V každej kapitole sa nachádza množstvo zaujímavých hlavolamov. Celá hra vyniká svojim dizajnom, ktorý vytvára príjemné, ale aj temné lokácie. Ak ste milovníkom nenásilných adventúr, The Dream Machine je pre vás skvelou voľbou, no nie s dlhou trvanlivosťou.

82%

18117150.review:
I'm not usually someone who gets into point-and-clicks - I usually get stuck or bored talking to people and I'm too guilty to use walkthroughs but I made it through the first 3 chapters with only one less-than-ovious head-scratching moment.

It's weird to look at, weird to play and so probably not for everyone but I love it - it's has a great balance of creepy and mysterious and it's quite original in places too.

Puzzles are tricky sometimes but there are no red herrings (tho I've no idea about the bench in Chapter 3!) and everything you need is reasonably easy to find if you look in the right places.  There are oo tiny changes in the cursor or 2-pixel-wide items - movement is quick - no convoluted dialogues to dig through - you mostly just play the game instead of walking, talking and so on.

Update: since writing that I've tried Chapter 4 and - unfortunately - I keep running into a crash bug which leaves me unable to continue.  This isn't ideal but hopefully the developer will address it/I'll figure out a different way around the problem - and the puzzles do seem a LOT harder in this episode too! :(

18108510.review:
You can just feel the developer's love and passion radiating from the game.

It is gorgeous. Nothing ever released has ever looked like this. It is clay and cardboard and little sets that were hand built and shot. So freaking cool.

The game was built by a small team, and based on reviews, it seems like it has had it's fair share of bugs. I saw none of them. The team has been on top of them, as evidenced by the regular updates and the fact none of the very minor glitches I saw affected the gameplay in any way. They were too minor to even mention. I have seen worse in AAA games. Development team cares about this game, and when I played, it was solid for all five chapters. 

The story is unique, fun, and engaging. The main story is simple, but the complexity of the dreams is where the magic happens. There are characters even within the dreams to interact it, and their responses to the very... well, odd dream circumstances they, as figments of a dream, are in, is spot on. I find all the dialogue to be very well written and thought out. The developers avoided much of the repetition you normally see when trying to put the square key in the round keyhole. This shows a lot of care and thought when even such minor details as "Item doesn't fit" type messages were considered and customized for most every circumstance.

The difficulty level is just right for the average adult or the clever teen (might be a bit scary for kids!). The puzzles are varied, and challenge you to think about things you have seen in your adventures and to combine them with new knowledge and items you aquire. It isn't just going room to room to solve a puzzle in each one, you are challenged to think about how the items in your inventory can interact with each other, the environment, other people, and help you achieve the task at hand.

I would have missed this game if a friend didn't gift me an extra copy. It has not gotten the attention it deserves. Don't miss this game if you have stumbled across it. I can't wait for the final chapter! I actually wish I had known there was one chapter left before I began playing, and waited to play the other ones until it was released. It sucked me in before I found out, and I couldn't put it down after I started playing!

Highest recommendation!

17964855.review:
Well the reviews are set so that I can only review against Chapter 1 and 2.  That's unfortunate.  This is a game that gets better as you play, so far Chapter 3 was incredibly dense and interesting, and Chapter 4 is set up to be much the same.

TL;DR Version:  10/10, would ruin my wife's dreams again.

I love point and click adventure games.  They are what I grew up with, and at the end of the day, it's the format I'm most comfortable with.  I've spent my time in WoW, and I loved it, and I recently spent two full working weeks worth of time beating the Witcher 3's storyline, and all of these are great experiences.  None of them can take me back to my childhood, the kernel of my gaming self, like a solid point and clicker.  And this is one of them.  This is an excellent point and click adventure game.  That's all it is, mind you, it's nothing more than that.  It's just what it's advertising -- and in its genre, it is absolutely superior.  The story is compelling, even for an old guy like me, the mechanics are fine, and the puzzle strength really isn't that hard if you're willing to stick with it.  

Yes, we only have walkthroughs for the first two chapters.  Thats ok.  Play around a bit and you WILL figure it out, and it will be way more rewarding than just reading through a walkthrough and beating the game in a few hours.  I promise, you can do it.  Remember when we had to order a hint book from Sierra back in the 80s, and by the time we got it, eight weeks later give or take, we figured out the puzzle?  There's no need for a hint book here.  Just keep at it.  And you'll feel a lot smarter when you figure it out all by yourself.

This game explores a thing that a lot of people have said a lot about, especially while in an altered state, the Dreamscape.  Ah, the Dreamscape, the Holy Grail of all game creators.  Quite possibly, the next bastion of virtual reality, if we really pick the thing apart.  Go read this review again on an energy drink or two.  If we had some sort of device that would let us fall asleep and log in while dreaming, lets be honest, that's another 6-10 hours a night we'd get to game.  That's all I'll tell you about the plot.  You don't need more.  Play the game.  It's fantastic.

17093115.review:
The Dream Machine n'est pas un jeu ordinaire et ça, ça se voit dès le premier coup d’œil : l’esthétique du jeu (je trouve ce terme plus approprié que "graphismes" dans le cas présent) n'est en rien semblable à d'autres jeux vidéos. Cela me rappelle plutôt certains dessins animés de mon enfance, alors on aime ou on aime pas mais on sent que le jeu a été conçu avec amour. Derrière chaque petit détail, une chaise, un pot de fleur, un tapis, on imagine des mains de grands enfants en train de modeler leur petit monde avec passion, et c'est ce que j'ai apprécié dans ce jeu (entre autres). http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=394604560 Dans ces deux premiers épisodes on découvre Victor Neff, le personnage principal et sa femme en plein emménagement. Lentement l'intrigue s'installe, la machine à rêves attise notre attention. La durée de vie des deux épisodes est à peu près semblable à celle d'un épisode car les suivants sont bien plus longs. Un peu lent à démarrer mais prometteur, on a très envie de jouer à la suite une fois ceux-ci terminés.

Sachez qu'en commençant à jouer aujourd'hui vous aurez accès aux chapitres 1-5 sur 6. Ayant moi-même acheté le bundle je pensais recevoir un jeu "fini" mais j'ai été un peu déçue de voir que le 6eme chapitre était encore en développement. Après, quand on voit le soin apporté aux décors et à l'élaboration des énigmes, notamment dans les épisodes suivants, on ne peut rien reprocher aux développeurs. 

Si vous êtes impatients comme moi attendez un peu mais n'oubliez pas de l'essayer dans quelques mois !


[i]Ci-dessous mon évaluation détaillée pour les prochains épisodes (sans spoilers mais je ne vous conseille pas de lire si vous voulez entièrement vous préserver).[/i]


[b]Chapitre 3[/b] :
Un chapitre bien plus long que les précédents où l'on sera amenés à visiter notre premier rêve. Les décors sont toujours aussi agréables et les énigmes commencent à être plus élaborées et plus complexes qu'auparavant.
Difficile de vous parler du scénario sans vous spoiler donc je dirai juste qu'il va falloir parcourir un paquebot de croisière, parler à l'équipage et mener l'enquête sur une disparition inquiétante pour arriver à vos fins. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=394604871 Le jeu va tout en se bonifiant, une bonne surprise !

[b]Chapitre 4[/b] :
Plus ça va et plus les chapitres sont bons ! Ici il vous faudra élaborer une recette pour entrer dans les rêves des habitants de l'immeuble et visiter le rêve de votre vieille voisine, Eddie. Vous serez amenés à résoudre une énigme très bien pensée à base de photographies pour réussir à la sauver. J'ai bien apprécié ce chapitre et l'on sent que les énigmes deviennent de plus en plus complexes et vous demanderont de faire preuve de beaucoup d'observation et de logique.

[b]Chapitre 5[/b] :
Le meilleur chapitre jusqu'ici à mon sens ! Les développeurs ont vu très grand pour celui-ci : les tableaux sont plus nombreux et la durée de vie élevée. Le jeu nous prouve à nouveau sa capacité à varier les décors et son inventivité en matière de casse-têtes. La vallée que l'on visite est pour moi le plus beau décor du jeu, ces extérieurs sont très soignés et on a plaisir à les parcourir même si les allers-retours sont très nombreux. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=398016156 Au niveau du scénario, sans trop vous spoiler je vous dirai que la frontière entre les rêves se fait de plus en plus mince et que Victor va découvrir deux "mondes" que tout oppose et pourtant liés. Mur oppressant, vols sanguinaires, géants et vampires, le jeu est loufoque, glauque, inventif, oppressant et maîtrisé de main de maître ! Vivement la suite !

[quote]Lisez d'autres avis sur ma page de curation : [b][url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/9002662/]Kitsune's Guide[/url][/b][/quote]

16583955.review:
Unquestionably, The Dream Machine's biggest selling point is its stop-motion animation style and aesthetics. It presents an almost surreal, otherworldly style that lends well to the game's focus on dreams. The story, while a bit dry and drawn out at times, is intriguing, light science fiction.

Many of the puzzles are your typical adventure game fare. Pick up this item, use it on this thing. Most puzzles aren't particuarly challenging, but most are intuitive enough that you won't be stuck for long. I admit to needing to check an FAQ once or twice, though.

Overall, it's definitely worth a look for fans of the adventure game genre. I wouldn't say it's worth the full price, but if you can get it on a decent sale, I would say get it.

16522901.review:
A great point and click game with a unique and painstakingly hand-crafted setting. The backgrounds are immersive and really atmospheric. At first the characters creeped me out as they have no eyes, but the creepiness works well with the game overall which is often quite dark.

The puzzles are challenging enough but not frustrating. They make logical sense despite the fantastical places you may end up in, which makes the puzzle solving satisfying.  

It has a good plot also - I found that I couldn't stop in between chapters as I just wanted to know what happens next (luckily the first 5 chapters were out when I bought it). The writers have done a good job of creating tension and uneasiness as well as characters that you actually care about. Delving into dreams opens up some crazy worlds and also deep back stories.

My only gripe would be some bugs in the latest chapter such as the game skipping you forward to a later point if you have loaded up an older save. Thankfully the game is constantly updated as the bugs are fixed.

Overall a well made, imaginative and immersive adventure game. Hopefully it won't be too long before the final chapter is out!

16454242.review: Beautiful! This game is totally worth the 20 hours of gameplay! Not as well known as it should be!

16371399.review:
Over the past couple years, I’ve become increasingly interested in the point-and-click genre. As a result, I’ve been buying such games whenever I can get them for a very low price. Of the ones I’ve played, The Dream Machine definitely ranks near the top. Your character, Victor Neff, has just moved into a small apartment building with his pregnant wife. He soon discovers something ominous happening in the building, and must travel through the dreams of his neighbors in order to stop it.

On the surface, the story does seem rather simplistic, and it is, to an extent. However, each dream you visit has its own story, and it is in these mini-stories where the game truly shines. These dreams range from bizarre, to sad, to creepy, and everywhere in between. There seems to be much more of an emphasis on showing, rather than telling. Simply traversing the dreams of your neighbors is enough to give you insight into their personalities. 

Another point of note with this game is that it is all crafted by hand, with clay and cardboard being the mediums of choice. The environments are, simply speaking, beautiful, and realizing it was all handmade gave me an even greater appreciation for the game. It also adds to the creepy atmosphere of the game, as many times characters are made to be rather grotesque in appearance.

Gameplay is your standard point-and-click style. You explore the environments, picking up items and using them to solve puzzles. The puzzles vary in difficulty, with some being quite easy and others being obnoxiously difficult and lacking in any sort of intuitiveness. And while the puzzles can be frustrating and take a while to solve, it is never so bad as to be game-breaking in the slightest.

TL;DR: The Dream Machine is one of the most incredible point-and-click games I’ve played. The atmosphere is truly unsettling, the environments are delightfully surreal, and the story is surprisingly engaging and had quite a bit of depth. The puzzles can sometimes be frustratingly difficult and there is no voice acting, but the good far outweighs the bad. I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys point-and-click and/or surreal games.

15765438.review:
This game has been in development for about 5 years now, so far 5 out of the planned 6 chapters have been finished. The reason it has taken so long is that the entire game is being built -by hand- with real materials like cardboard, clay and wood. It is absolutely beautiful, as you can probably imagine. Not only that, but the story AND the writing are both terrific! I'd say that almost all the puzzles hold some sense of logic to them, but as this is a game about entering people's dreams, it somewhat fittingly DOES start to lose some of it's sanity with it's puzzles (as is the case with all adventure games unfortunately). I had to use a walkthrough a few times to complete it, but that's the case with pretty much any adventure game I've ever played...

I absolutely recommend playing this! It's not finished yet, and based on how long it's taken to get the first 5 chapters out, it seems like we'll be waiting a while yet for the ending, but it's a wait very much worth enduring!

As with many of the games in my Steam catalog, I got this one in a bundle. Not being a huge fan of 'point and click' games I decided to give 'Dream Machine' and chance one rainy afternoon when I was bored with the usual third or first person shooters, and was pleasantly surprised with my discovery. I also found it refreshing that the game was broken up into several different chapters, each entirely different than the one that preceded it. 14575265.review: Una grata sorpresa ha sido The Dream Machine. Es una aventura gráfica por capítulos. Me entraron los 4 primeros capítulos en un bundle en el que me interesaban otros juegos, pero este me ha encantado. La temática es onírica, no quiero desvelar mucho de la trama, pero tiene toques de introspección bastante madura, ciencia ficción y esos mundos oníricos. El aspecto visual es de plastilina, todo realista, tipo stop motion, como jugar una película (muy fantasiosa) de Wallace & Gromit. El primer capítulo introduce la historia y sube mucho hacia el final cuando se van desvelando las cosas, el segundo es soberbio. El tercero se me hizo más aburrido, pero una vez más acaba en alto. Y el cuarto me ha parecido maravilloso. Estoy deseando que saquen el sexto capítulo para comprar el quinto y sexto y acabar el juego. Tiene algunas mecánicas originales, aunque la mayoría son las de una aventura gráfica, coger cosas, combinarlas, usarlas, hablar con gente... Pero no me puedo resistir a comentar una mecánica del capítulo 4 que me ha encantado (puede considerarse SPOILER): Hay una parte donde colgando unos cuadros de habitaciones de una pared cambias el orden de esas habitaciones en la casa, pudiendo acceder así a nuevos sitios (y consiguiendo nuevos cuadros). El juego está sin traducir, y para aprovecharlo hay que tener un nivel de lectura en inglés adecuado. Si lo tienes muy recomendable.

The Dream Machine is a twisted, dreamlike, sometimes disturbingly nightmarish point-and-click game done in clay animation style.
Gameplay 7.5 out of 10
The puzzles are mostly point and click some are quite easy to solve and some are a bit tricky and even a bit absurd.
Graphics 9/10
Pure honest hard work done by the hands of “sexy Swedish guys”.9 Points for the unique, morbid style. I really really like the clay graphic style. Two Thumbs up for the game devs for putting such a heck load of work into this game.
Music 8/10
Dreamlike, ominous sounds, which nicely add to the atmosphere
Story 9/10 
The story is intriguing and sometimes even a bit disturbing and grim. To make it short, without spoiling anything, you travel through the dreams of various people with the help of the Dream Machine. 
I'd say definitely a must buy for all point-and-click gamers and casual gamers. Although a bit grim and disturbing sometimes

The Dream Machine is an award-winning adventure game about dreams and voyeurism.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WRQwgTfWg_E
It's built by hand using materials such as clay and cardboard. In Chapter 1 of the 6 part Dream Machine series, you play as Victor Neff, the husband in a young couple who've just moved into a new apartment. While trying to get settled in you discover that all is not as it seems in the quiet, unassuming apartment building... In Chapter 2, Victor goes to confront the landlord, Mr. Morton, only to find his apartment empty. Can Victor find the elusive landlord in time and is there more to Mr. Morton than meets the eye? - Recommended!

13752587.review:
The Dream Machine is an episodic point-and-click adventure game about a guy who has to kill a machine which subsists by sticking its tentacles into peoples' dreams and feeding off of them. This is actually what happens. 

Chapter 1 of the game serves as an introduction to the main character, Victor Neff, his wife Alicia, and the new apartment building they have moved into. The Neffs are pretty endearing characters — they can be snarky, but they also show genuine affection for each other, and I like Victor's haircut a lot, if it could even be called that. There's also a lot of flavor text in this opening chapter; I'd go as far as to say there's a unique line of dialogue for every incorrect item use and attempted combination, and the majority of them are quite funny. The chapter ends at a rather odd point (I'd describe it as a cliffhanger with no dramatic tension) but since the first two chapters come bundled together it's not too bad.

Chapter 2 introduces the Dream Machine itself, its background, and the dream diving mechanic I presume will be used throughout the rest of the game. To be honest, the dream explored in this chapter is kind of dull — it's a few screens of cloudy rockland that, while soothing, isn't as fantastical as I'd like to see in a game that focuses on dreams.

Chapter 3's dream takes place on a flying cruise filled with tons of Victor clones. While the concept sounds interesting, it isn't really utilized to any extent outside of one puzzle, making it seem more like a cost-cutting measure than anything else. This is also the chapter where I started to feel that the unique flavor text was forgotten or cut for time, because most of the lines for incorrect actions were along the lines of "that won't work." It was rather disappointing to try out quirky combinations only for the game to not care as much as it used to. At the very least the ending was fairly touching. This is the last chapter I finished thus far.

The clay-cardboard aesthetic the game uses is quite pleasing to the eyes. The environments are modeled with intricate detail and the character models are what I'd call creepy but cute. The sound design is great too; for the most part the music in the game is atmospheric background noise I'd certainly call "dreamlike," but there are also musical stings at times which really add emotion to events like turning a book page to discover something terrifying. While there isn't any voice acting, there is a text-to-speech option that can be turned on which uses the exact same voice as the one for Mumble and I personally find that hilarious.

Unfortunately, it must be said that the engine this game uses is terrible. The Dream Machine runs on Adobe Flash, which has been used for other games like The Binding of Isaac and Machinarium, but it simply does not work as well here. Character animations, instead of being made of sprites like in those games, appear to be made from video clips that, at least on my end, take like a half-second to load each time they happen. This includes basic actions like walking, so every time I clicked to make Victor move the game would hang for a moment before he trots off. It just doesn't seem as smooth as it could be, and it doesn't help that on several occasions the game bugged out and failed to load the next scene, causing me to have to quit out and reload to around five minutes earlier.

Overall, I lean slightly in favor of recommending this game, at least for now. It can be plodding at times, and the puzzles can be both too simple and too obtuse, but I like the environments and the plot has kept me interested enough to see how it will end.

Recenzja dotyczy już wydanych aktów 1-5. Wciąż czekamy na szósty odcinek tej niesamowitej przygodówki.

Uwielbiam gry tworzone jak rzeźby. Zamiast komputerowego generowania grafiki, mamy tu karton i glinę, przez co produkcja nabiera unikalnego charakteru. W przeciwieństwie do ojca gatunku, Neverhooda, The Dream Machine nie jest produkcją dla dzieci. Swym mrocznym klimatem przypomina raczej również zrobionego z gliny The Swapper, ale nie męczy tak mózgu gracza egzystencjalnymi pytaniami, zamiast tego stawiając na oniryczny świat pełen niedopowiedzeń. 

W tej opowieści zwiedzamy marzenia senne lokatorów pewnej kamienicy. Sny, które na poczatku wydają się sielanką mogą w mig okazać się koszmarem. Choć już akt drugi jest niepokojący, to zakończenie trzeciego nazwę już drastycznym - gra zdecydowanie nie nadaje się dla dzieci. Muszę pochwalić zagadki, które są jak najbardziej logiczne, choć czasem jest to logika snu - jak choćby użycie parasola przeciwsłonecznego jako parasolki w drinku ;) Udżwiękowienie jest bardzo dobre, potrafi wywołać gęsią skórkę. Niestety gra pozbawiona jest dubbingu, wszystkie kwestie czytamy.

Niestety choć The Dream Machine jest ciągle w produkcji i systematycznie usuwane są bugi z wszystkich aktów, nadal  potrafi niespodziewanie się zawiesić, dlatego warto często zapisywać grę.

The tl;dr - Great game, unique art style, challenging puzzles. It's provided me hours of entertainment per chapter. I think it's worth it.

The full rundown:

The game's unique art style of clay and cardboard was honestly a bit unnerving at first. As it progressed I began to appreciate it more and more. The art style really sets the tone for the game. The music and sounds are also really great and well-chosen. Not overly repetitive, I like to listen to it.

The game play is simple and easy to navigate. There's a lot to explore. The puzzles are not always easy! They keep you thinking and I'll admit to getting seriously stuck and having to seek out help from the internet more than once. That being said there are plenty of resources out there to help you keep progressing.

I hear the release schedule for the chapters is kind of sporradic, but there are 5 out already. Only one left to go.

I think it's worth it.

Oh boy, would I recommend The Dream Machine. I've just recently gotten into point-and-clicks and I think this just set a high standard and it's going to be hard to find a game that beats it. As an artist, this is a game to appreciate, and as someone who enjoys 'darker' art, it's a smorgasbord. 

Reasons why you need it: 
+ Devs are very responsive to cries for help with glitches
+ Art style is incredible and obviously takes a lot of work
+ Puzzles are really tough
+ Puzzles are innovative and different
+ Chapter format makes it easier to appreciate in moderation instead of doing a binge

There are some little glitches here and there, but your love for the game will overpower them. Community for this game is great as well. There are no cons, really. Although, I would love to see some dynamic backgrounds.

The puzzles are often difficult but not impossible, the tone is both dark and comic. I haven't been this impressed with a pure, puzzle solver point and click game since Grim Fandango and Monkey Island.

Some puzzles are a little harder than I care for and chalking up some of these solutions to "LOL DREAM LOGIC" gets tired after a while. As a whole the game is great and you'd be doing yourself a favor experiencing this little adventure.

12112585.review:
Typically, with episodic games, each chapter is produced within a reasonable time frame.  When I purchased this game in December of 2012, I paid for a complete game and wholly believed that delivery of a final product would be imminent.

Four years have elapsed since my purchase and the final chapter has yet to be released.*  It's been two years since the release of any new content and six years since the introduction of the first chapter.  Not only hasn't the game been finalized, but the developer can't even provide an estimated release date for the final chapter.  They have, however, posted some news recently--I've been happily informed that they are enjoying themselves in Switzerland and getting drunk off absinthe.  Seriously, that's what they said.

Now I may not know a lot of things, but there's one thing I am sure of--I'm not a bank, I don't give loans to people so they can develop products at their leisure, I don't take part in crowdsourcing, I never buy Early Access, and I definitely would not have purchased this game, or any other game, knowing that it would be at least four years until I experienced its conclusion.  I would not buy a game that I would play for 3 hours, then put down for several years, only to pick it back up again, smack dab in the middle of the story, just to play for another 3 hours.  Who the fuck, in their right mind, would knowingly hand their money over to someone so they could do that?  No one, that's who.  No one would--it's absurd.  Now, knowing that I would never consciously do such a thing, I can only conclude that there has been some amount of deception involved concerning the sale of this game.

I may not have asked when the final chapter would be released, but I did not have any reason to believe it would be at least 4 years until that occurred.  Being a linear point-and-click adventure game, with each chapter only a few hours long and having no replay value, it really doesn't make any sense for someone to sell this type of game piecemeal if there was going to be several years between each chapter's release.  I think it's quite reasonable to assume that this game would have been fully developed within a short span of time--several months, perhaps a year at the most.  Early Access did not exist at that time and I had no reason to believe that Steam was in the business of selling games that were at the beginning of a 6+ year development cycle.

Based on my experience with this title, I will never make the mistake of purchasing another incomplete, [i]episodic[/i] game again and I will definitely not be supporting this developer, by any means, in any of their future endeavors.

*The final chapter was released yesterday, May 12, 2017--five years, five months since my purchase.


For reference, here are the chapter release dates and the time that had elapsed between them:

Chapters 1 and 2 - December 2010
Chapter 3 - October 2011 (10 months)
Chapter 4 - August 2013 (1 year, 10 months)
Chapter 5 - November 2014 (1 year, 3 months)
Chapter 6 - May 2017 (2 years, 6 months)

Total time since the first chapter's release: 6 years, 5 months
Average time between chapters: 1 year, 7 months


This review was edited on May 13, 2017.

11535860.review:
Questo gioco è speciale. Talmente speciale che si merita un parere ancor prima che la serie finisca. Siamo al quarto dei sei capitoli che formano la fantastica avventura di The Dream Machine, e alla fine di ognuno di essi ti senti sollevato e spaventato allo stesso tempo. Sollevato, perché sei riuscito a cavartela tra rompicapi vari (ma comunque sia abbastanza intuitivi, e che richiedono solo uno sforzo un tantino sopra la media per essere risolti); spaventato, perché non vuoi avvicinarti alla conclusione di questo viaggio unico nel suo genere. The Dream Machine travalica il senso comune di avventura grafica, perché trae il suo punto di forza da ogni singolo elemento di ogni singola area di gioco: ognuna di esse è viva, respira della magnifica semplicità della clay motion, ti ingloba tanto da farti sentire quell'odore pungente di argilla con la quale ti sporcavi le mani alle elementari. E ancora le musiche, un ambient onirico, emozionante, unico, indispensabile per completare i diversi quadretti brulicanti di vita dei quali il gioco si compone. E ultimi, ma non meno importanti, i personaggi. Ogni singolo personaggio è come se fosse un nostro conoscente di vecchia data. Il protagonista, Victor, con il suo fare fatalista, sempre tranquillo anche nelle situazioni più assurde ed impensabili che affronterà, è uno specchio neutro e cristallino di ogni gamer. Ma le emozioni le senti, le sue e quelle degli altri compagni di avventura, in un mondo dove non c'è bene o male, ma soltanto trascinanti gorghi emozionali dentro le insospettabili vite di piccoli pupazzetti di argilla, sfogliate fino al nucleo stesso della loro anima attraverso rompicapi più o meno originali. Un gioco davvero, ma davvero speciale. Coinvolgente, emozionante, a tratti ironico e sarcastico, ma anche oscuro e inquietante, The Dream Machine entra nel mio cuore assieme alle altre avventure grafiche "particolari" come quelle dell'Amanita Design, con le quali condivide le perfette atmosfere musicate, ma che in più porta con sé una sceneggiatura e dei dialoghi suggestivi e mai noiosi. Da avere assolutamente, se non si era ancora capito.
Aggiornamento a caldo dopo aver finito il capitolo 5: Forse il capitolo più difficile da risolvere, ed anche il più largo da esplorare (gli sviluppatori affermano infatti che il suo gameplay equivale a quello di tutti i capitoli precedenti messi assieme). 45 nuove bellissime ambientazioni dettagliate in maniera certosina, nuovi intrighi, nuovi ragionamenti filosofici oltre la soglia del tangibile, un doppio sogno con il suo labile confine da affrontare, ed il finale che alimenta la straziante attesa dell'ultimo capitolo di un'avventura unica e straordinaria come poche.

Possibly one of my favourite games ever! Really amazing storytelling, visuals, music, and gameplay. The puzzles are complex without being absolutlely impossible, and there's no totally bizarre solutions. Just about everything makes sense within the context of the world, and it's a really engaging world for the chapters that have been released so far. If you'd prefer to play it all at once, I'd wait untill all the chapters are released: but if you don't mind the wait, buy it now for sure. 

My only current dislike is that there's not a huge reason to replay it due to a lack of randomly generated puzzles, but given the length of what's already out I'd say it's pretty worth what it gives. However, I still personally find it fun to replay, if only to choose dialogue options I didn't choose before, or just to see the amazing art.

The Dream Machine is a surrealistic point-and-click game that’s been created using clay and cardboard. Placing you in what seems like a typical apartment building, you soon discover that your landlord and the apartment itself is not what it seems. The puzzles are not extremely difficult to figure out and sadly, there’s very little replay value once you’ve played through. The characters are well designed and the environments are extremely fun to walk through. Any point-and-click fans of Maniac Mansion and Monkey Island will enjoy Dream Machine for it’s familiar gameplay, interesting backgrounds and conning storyline. A must play game for anyone looking for a new take on a classic gaming genre.

Dang. That was some creepy fun. Going into this I thought it would be just like any other point and click game; I was mostly drawn by the concept of dreams (and admittedly the very low price of the entire bundle during the last sale).

Some of the puzzles were extremely difficult and I found myself having to try many things before I found the correct way to solve them... and I'm guilty of cheating and looking for solutions online when things got too hard to the point where I'm totally stumped. Also, the claymation worked perfectly with the theme of the game, and gave it a more eerie vibe. 

Of all four chapters so far, I enjoyed Chapter 3 the most; I thought it was the creepiest of them all, especially with the way it ended. I was disappointed to find that Chapter 4 wasn't as long, and now I'm impatient for the last two. 

The only problem I have with the game is that it sometimes froze up or crashed; however, there's an autosave feature so not much damage was done. Other than that, I really enjoyed it!

10410718.review:
Review for chapters 1-4:

I'll keep this really short despite myself, because there really is only one thing to be said: This game is ridiculously good.

The visual style is mindblowing, the music is great, the puzzles are smart and mostly interesting, with occasionally even unique mechanics in later chapters. And the story is far more mature and interesting than one expects. Though if Tim Burton has taught us anything, it's that claymotion has a tendency to turn the cute into something surreal, unsettling, even horrifying at times. As the chapters progress, things go from banal to weird to scary, like in some old Stephen King novels. The puzzles also advance in difficulty, and while they are occasionally hard, they are mostly logical, and generally feel well worth the effort. Take the time to think and try out things, this isn't a game that wants to be rushed through.

A really memorable, really gorgeous, really fun to play puzzle adventure. Worth every penny.

10328872.review: Before I write anything else, I need to say that I can't wait for next chapters! This haunting point and click adventure reminded me of the Neverhood because of the claymation, but that is where the similarities end. The Dream Machine is disturbing and dark game about dreams and a house where something is terribly wrong. Some parts are quite relaxing, some are really creepy. The Dream Machine has many strong points like interesting characters, catching visual side and soundtrack, but the best is definitely how the game builds the atmosphere. Grab this if you can, it's worth the price, despite the chapters being quite short.

10318355.review:
I bought this game a while ago as an episodic package after seeing it on the front page of Steam. I was taken by the look of it and I am a fan of point-and-click adventure games. I'm still very happy that I stumbled upon this game.

The artwork is amazing and adds a depth to the game that complements the story very well. The few animations that are present feel natural for the artstyle even if they aren't perfectly smooth. I can appreciate the time that goes into creating each scene in this game.

The story has been very captivating thus far. It builds up very well and I feel very anxious to continue the story after each chapter. Although it would be nice to have audio instead of full text, it is very easy reading with short clips of text instead of walls.

The actual gameplay is pretty generic for a point-and-click adventure game with puzzles and a fair amount of walking from room to room using simple clicks for mechanics and a few drags to piece things together. For a real story-driven adventure game, though, I can deal with simple mechanics that allow for greater concentration on the puzzles, story, etc.

The developers are working hard at keeping the game updated and fixing any known bugs or issues. Fortunately, I haven't come across any issues with the game, myself. They've been constantly refining and adding to the game so it's likely better to pick up a copy later in development. It has been released on more and more platforms as the game ages.

The only real qualm that I have with the game is the extremely slow release of the chapters. When I purchased the game, I believe chapter 3 was just being released or had just been released. The release date for chapter 3 was October 31, 2011. To put the delays into context, chapter 4 was just released August 6th, 2013. I'm never one to mind waiting for a delay on a release for a well-refined product but that was a bit extreme. Fortunately, the developers have mentioned a release for chapter 5 in just months instead of years. Here's hoping. A miserable part of waiting so long is you have to revisit places and puzzles you've done in previous chapters; however, the game is quaint enough and easy enough to follow that forgetting shouldn't be a problem for most.

Overall, I would definitely recommend this game. The price isn't bad and it does go on sale on Steam. There is a demo available on the official website that allows you to play the entirety of chapter 1 through your browser. I'd say that the demo, at least, is a must-play. http://www.thedreammachine.se/

9874714.review:
Ottimo inizio per un'avventura grafica desueta e intrigante. Non potrei essere più entusiasta, essendo il tema trattato il mio preferito: l'ambito onirico. Grafica sporca in polymer clay, con ambientazioni suggestive e calde, davvero tridimensionali. E' stato come tornare a giocare pupazzi, potendo godere visivamente di quanto può creare la fantasia. Buoni enigmi, lineari. Non capita mai di incappare in risoluzioni fortuite o in elementi poco congrui con l'avanzare delle proprie intuizioni. 
Buone musiche di sottofondo, personaggi piacevoli e interessanti, anche se accennati.
Le situazioni e le sensazioni sono vivide, ma lasciano un'eco nelle proprie fantasie, proprio come nei sogni. Non è un gioco dove l'esperienza del giocatore sovrasta la trama (come in "the path", per intenderci), ma immagino che ogni partita lasci un segno e delle impressioni nettamente diverse e individuali per ogni giocatore. Qualcuno potrà trovarlo inquietante, qualcuno fiabesco. Io lo trovo "rasserenante" e in linea con il tono di quanto provo nei miei sogni. E' un gioco che va ben osservato e ascoltato per essere capito, perché al di là di qualsiasi significato nella trama, come un qualsiasi sogno, ha un livello comunicativo diverso. Il segno, il significante, l'atmosfera. Sono queste le note notevoli del gioco.

Ben scritto, anche se molti dialogni tendono ad essere lunghi, e potrebbe non essere piacevole per tutti.
Animazione mediocre, salvata dall'elemento plastilina che giustifica e sopperisce.

Amo molto questi visi sgradevoli e incisi. Le figure sono splendide.

Ho giocato anche agli altri capitoli. Anche in virtù di questo non posso che consigliare fortemente l'esperienza.

9244623.review:
Very fun and surreal. The humor is pretty funny and the horror is... actually kind of disturbing. While I can't say the dream portions opperate on actual dream logic, they can certainly make you forget that it doesn't, and figuring out the internal logic of each individual dream is pretty fun in itself. And I'd be lying if I said I didn't get a kick out of the subtle [i]The Prisoner[/i] shoutout in Chapter 1.

I am, however, struck by how lucid the various dreamers are once you find them, not to mention weirdly capable of taking the whole bizzare scenario in stride. Then again, considering the sorts of things I'm able to take in stride in my own dreams that would weird the hell out of me in real life, I suppose they aren't quite so lucid after all. But this is neither the time nor place for those stories.

My only complaints are that A) a few of the puzzles are terribly inconveniant to complete, even after you've figured out the solution, you're given a hell of a runaround to actually put that solution into action. And B) the chapters are over too quickly. I hope the next two chapters are longer.

9237071.review: The Dream Machine is a pretty simple point and click adventure game. The puzzles, like most point and click games, range from stupidly easy to esoteric beyond belief but this game manages to have a pretty consistent degree of difficulty. Unlike a lot of point and click games the puzzles reveal themselves through interacting with the environment and being patient, not many puzzles require outside help to finish or understand. The art style in this game is really interesting, I believe they used claymation to model everything in the game which makes for a really unique style. The only complaint I have about that is that the characters are horrifying, especially the wife character but then again maybe that’s the artist’s intent. The story is alright but nothing to write home about. I don’t know how to fix it but they had the ability to make something super interesting and out there, like Twin Peaks, but it just kinda falls short and feels like a semi-surreal romantic drama. Another complaint I have about the game is the length, ~45 minutes a chapter is too much to ask $5 fo. So while I enjoyed this game I don’t think I’ll pick up the last two chapters unless I see them on sale. Overall it was enjoyable, if you own it I suggest giving it a play through if you don’t I suggest wait for a sale to pick it up.

9141796.review:
I really don't write reviews very often. However, I felt that this one really deserved one. 

The Short: 
This is an incredibly well-designed game. The developer's were able to capture that very rare "spark." While it may be a little short (I really took my time and it took me an hour per chapter), it is one of immense quality. Overall 9.5/10.

The Longer: 
- Gameplay: 
It is your standard point-and-click adventure game. You are given a small story or situation and you have to solve puzzles to progress. My only real complaint, which isn't much of a complaint, is the sudden advancement in difficulty. In the first two chapters, I didn't really come across any problems/difficulties. The third chapter was really hard! You'll understand when you have to make a certain drink. 

- Music: 
I loved the soundtrack. It matches the situations and environment very, very well. It ranges from the caretaker's creepy jazz song to minimalistic ambience to Silent Hill-esque rhythms.  

- Story: 
This is easily one of my favorite stories that has come from recent gaming. Without giving too much away, it begins as a simple tale about a couple moving into a new apartment. Soon, it evolves into an (without exaggeration) epic adventure involving the dream world, a science project gone wrong, and horror. 

- Graphics/Environment: 
The clay animation was a really smart artistic choice. It helps to add a fresh perspective on the genre. The environments are all interesting and enchanting. The characters are... scary looking. 

To the developers, I sincerely enjoyed your game.

Faszinierendes Point&Click Abenteuer mit ausgewogenem Schwierigkeitsgrad. Zuerst verstehe ich gar nicht, was zu tun ist, nach ein paar Minuten habe ich dann aber den Überblick, doch manchmal kann es eine halbe Ewigkeit dauern, bis ich ein Rätsel lösen kann. Immer kurz bevor ich im Netz nach einer Lösung suchen will, schaffe ich dann aber die Aufgabe: Für mich ein ausgezeichnetes Balancing.
Die Geschichte selbst ist düster aber amüsant erzählt, im Großen und Ganzen geht es um einen "Wissenschaflter", der ungfragt anderer Leute Träume anzapft, um eine Traumkarte zu erstellen. Details will ich hier nicht verraten, die Story versorgt euch während des Spiels mit Einzelheiten. 
Kapitel 1 & 2 führen euch in das Spiel und die Geschichte ein, Kapitel 3 ist ganz dem Traum eurer Lebensgefährting gewidmet und Kapitel 4 führt euch tiefer in die intime Traumwelt der weiteren Mitbewohner eures Hauses ein. 
Einziger Wermutstropfen: Die Abstände zwischen den Veröffentlichungen der einzelnen Kapitel kann schmerzhaft lange dauern, wir reden hier von Monaten und Jahren :-) 
Trotzdem, Daumen hoch und eine klare Empfehlung von mir, innovative Rätsel mit schicker Grafik und ausgezeichnetem Gameplay bei diesem Preis, das kommt nicht oft vor!

8030054.review:
The Dream Machine is, by far, one of the most complicated adventure games I've ever played. 

You play as a man who has just moved with his wife to a new apartment. Something is amiss, however, and soon you learn that you'll have to take it upon yourself to stop a sinister plot where your dreams, and the dreams of all the apartment residents, are being infiltrated by your land lord and his out of control contraption. The graphics are marvelously creepy, being claymation, and the soft ambeint music and horror-like storyline set the scene for a truly challenging adventure that will have you immersed for hours. 

Game play wise, I will say that some of the puzzles may be easy to solve in a few minutes, and other may take hours, or even days, depending on your thought process and how you deal with puzzles. There are puzzles for all types of people, so while I certainly don't suggest that you cheat, it's always fun to team up on this game. Some of the game play can get slightly monotonous while you're stuck, which can be frustrating. (But such is the bane of adventure games.) There were also a few times where I thought I was supposed to be trying to solve a puzzle to unlock something, but it wasn't time for that in the story yet. Still, when things become clear, it's easy to sit down and focus on the puzzle intently.

The story line is creepy and unsettling. It is not a full out horror tale, but at times it can be graphic and disturbing. It also moves slowly towards the disturbing, and as you get further into the plot it becomes stranger. 

This IS the sort of adventure game where you may need to keep some scrap paper beside you in order to jot down notes and figure things out. If you are not into complicated adventure games, then this is not for you. But if you are, then welcome to The Dream Machine.

The puzzles are good enough, they're reasonable and you'll not have to try combinations of objects  desperately trying to guess because of bad designing. You may found some difficult at the main/last puzzle of each chapter - they're hard, but not nonsensical.

It is a collection of great and beautiful craftwork, but it doesn't try to stand by the art itself, being part of a very good story with solid gameplay, so it's a great game.

If you're those who like point-and-click adventures, mostly with good stories, this is a game for you.

7790860.review:
The Dream Machine è un’avventura grafica episodica che va avanti da novembre 2011. Pian piano gli sviluppatori di questo gioco – creato interamente a mano con cartoni e materiale riciclabile (oltre al pongo pongoso) – hanno pubblicato fino a oggi ben quattro capitoli su sei della loro storia. Si tratta di un gioco dalle tinte filo-thriller con una spruzzata di fantascienza, in cui verrete facilmente catturati a partire dal secondo capitolo (il primo è quasi un tutorial), per poi perdervi con i successivi. Come già detto precedentemente, nelle recensioni dei primi due e del terzo capitolo, il team svedese ne sa a pacchi: già a partire dalla realizzazione pratica, sono rimasto sorpreso e colpito per il grandissimo lavoro effettuato, anche considerando il fatto che, almeno per le ultime avventure del panorama, l’occhio viene fortemente coccolato o da una grafica aggiornata, o da un gusto retrò. The Dream Machine va un po’ contro entrambe, offrendo la sua particolare scelta senza sfigurare minimamente.

Vieni a leggere la recensione completa su TheShelterNetwork.com:
http://theshelternetwork.com/the-dream-machine-capitolo4/
http://www.theindieshelter.com/the-dream-machine-3/

6256344.review:
Una de las mejores aventuras gráficas que he jugado en Steam, sin duda alguna. Recientemente llegó la última entrega de la misma y por fin, después de varios años, pude terminarla. Veámosla con un poco de detalle...
En "The Dream Machine" controlamos a Victor Neff, que junto con su pareja, se mudan a un apartamento en un bloque de edificios. Allí encontrará una serie de peculiares vecinos, lugares secretos y sucesos extraños que llevará al monigote Victor Neff a viajar a la mente de todos los habitantes del edificio a través de una máquina de los sueños ([i]dream machine[/i] es máquina de sueños, para los burros ignorantes). La historia es una mezcla de terror - ciencia ficción - onirismo, donde unas veces destacará más un aspecto y otras veces otro. El tema, así como los diálogos, tocan temas profundos en algunas ocasiones. A mí, la temática me ha flipado mogollón, si lo que queréis es que la describa en lenguaje técnico.
Los puzzles son muy elaborados, y en ocasiones, algo difíciles y rocambolescos, que no todo va a ser [i]monerías[/i] "Artifex Mundi". Me ha parecido ejemplar la habilidad del creador para hilar unas cosas con otras, y crear puzzles totalmente integrados en el juego y que van más allá de un capítulo u otro. A él le dedico los 15 bourbons que me tomaré esta noche.
El aspecto técnico es una preciosidad. Mirad las capturas: construido con cartón, arcilla y brócoli, como la misma descripción del juego dice, da como resultado escenarios maravillosos, iluminados manualmente de forma magistral. Mira por dónde, van a ser 16 los bourbons, que se lo merece.
El sonido no es abundante (más bien, la palabra es "comedido"), es exactamente como debe ser, y casa a la perfección con el desarrollo del juego, sumergiéndonos en la extraña atmósfera que nos presenta la historia.
Como me la pela todo y no tengo miedo en mear fuera de tiesto y esas cosas, diré que este juego me parece una verdadera obra de arte, de la que se ha hablado poco para lo que se merece. ¡Coñe!

Comfortably designed, cleverly written, and visually interesting.
Beautiful game. Sets are beautifully photographed. Very manageable but true to the adventure game way in its inventory. Puzzles are fair. There are either amusing or disturbing comments on most things when attempting to force item interaction. As for the themes and my response, as a skeptic of that certain and too often reinforced mystic attitude towards dreams, I didn't expect the game to make me any sort of believer. Not quite, still, but by this game's insight and style, I feel changed, though always I had to acknowledge the influence our dreams have on us in recollection, or the reliability and vividness of our recall. However dreamy the experience was, *this* "recollection" is assuredly *definite.*

3821402.review:
Молодая пара, ждущая ребёнка, переезжает в новую квартиру, находит странную предостерегающую записку предыдущего жильца, а дальше начинаются и вовсе слабо-объяснимые события, которые довольно скоро достигнут невероятных масштабов. 

Крутая сюрреалистичная драма с элементами детектива и триллера с путешествиями во снах, жутковатых, но неизменно красивых и изобретательных, с чудесными, остроумными диалогами, философскими дилеммами и всегда разумными квестовыми задачками. За всю игру мы заглянули в гайд лишь один раз в четвёртой главе. 

Восхитительно выглядящий пластелиновый квест два шведа [url=http://dreammachinegame.blogspot.ru/2009/09/lorem-ipsum-dolor-sit-amet.html]начали делать ещё в 2009-м году[/url]. В мае 2012-го в стиме появились первые две главы, а финальная шестая вышла, наконец, в мае 2017-го, ровно пять лет спустя (или восемь, если считать от начала разработки). 

Что случилось за эти годы? Да можно сказать, возникла практически вся современная игровая сцена: Supergiant Games, Klei, новый XCOM, FTL, [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/alpasy/recommended/231160]The Swapper[/url] (с похожей "графикой" из подручных материалов), Тим Шафер вернулся с [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/alpasy/recommended/232790]новыми квестами[/url] и римейками старых, Daedalic Entertainment успешно закрепились в жанре, который все давно считали мёртвым, неожиданным образом графические новеллы прочно заняли свою собственную нишу, интерактивное кино Telltale Games, наконец. Авторы легендарного пластилинового Neverhood успели собрать деньги и вылепить игру по мотивам, [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/alpasy/recommended/334120]достаточно средненькую[/url] на мой взгляд. А "Машина Сновидений" всё это время где-то неспешно бурлила, выплёвывала методичные обновления раз в полгода, исследовала границы страны снов. И что же в итоге получилось? 

Получилось, как я уже сказал, совершенно невероятного качества квест - интригующий, увлекательный, забавный, не устающий удивлять. Каждая глава выдержана в своей собственной тональности и чуть ли не в своём жанре. Очень понравились в пятой главе диалоги с безумным рыцарем, сошедшим будто со "Святого грааля" Монти Пайтонов ("Кто скелет, я скелет? Да это просто лёгкое ранение"), а также разбросанные тут и там трогательные моменты, и общая подковёрная мораль сюжета ([spoiler]про парня, который просто хотел как следует выспаться, а не вот этого вот груза ответственности[/spoiler]). 

Ещё интересно, как первые главы были сравнительно небольшими, по два часа на каждую, а финальные три вошли во вкус, набрали обороты, и в общем итоге игра переваливает за двадцать часов. И она определённо того стоит. Единственный недостаток тут - отсутствие перевода на русский (и другие языки, собственно). Впрочем, я бы не сказал, что язык здесь супер-сложный - он ведь иностранный и для самих авторов. 

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1101550376

В целом определённо лучший квест, который мы когда-либо играли. Надеюсь, шведы ещё чем-нибудь порадуют в будущем [i](только как следует выспятся).[/i]

3643346.review:
This is quite a decent adventure game. There are a few cases of "adventure game logic", like having to put ink on the unconscious man's hand then get his palm-print on a piece of paper to use with the palm-scanning door lock instead of just dragging the guy over to the door and pressing his hand to it, but most of the puzzles make sense (and the ones that don't are at least not difficult to figure out) and it doesn't make the common adventure game mistake of trying too hard to be funny.

It's not up to the standard of games like the Blackwell series or Hector: Badge of Carnage, but it's not bad.
