I must admit I did use a walkthrough throughout most of it; this hilarious Norwegian guy really helped (See GaffermanTV on youtube), who went through the beta of the game but it was interesting to see what was changed in the final game. Although it was mostly minor changes but one part of the game towards the end of Chapter 3 where they changed the way of solving a puzzle because it appeared to not make sense to the aforementioned Norwegian Guy (unless it is randomized).

Can't wait for Chapters 4 and 5.

4695187.review:
Although it took me only me my two days off work to complete I wasn't disappointed with this one! 

Part of a bundle I bought a while ago it includes three of five chapters. I'm assuming the other two haven't been made yet. 

This game has a storyline which is weird, creepy and disturbing. The graphics only serve to compliment its strange and peculiar theme. Think LittleBigPlanet and a Sackboy character only scary. 

There's a few interesting puzzles that will have you smiling when you solve them too which gives you that satisfactory feeling of a good puzzler. 

To name a downside would be that there's no voice, just text for speech, but that's no problem. It just means the game is very quiet most of the time!

703870.review:
The Dream Machine was ok. It's a surreal point and click done with real models that give the game the feel of it taking place in a 3d diarama. Only the first three chapters of supposed five are out now. The developers are rather coy about if/when the next ones will be made. It's a shame because the story is just picking up by the end of chapter three. Definitely wait until the game is finished before buying.

2017 update now that the full game is released:
Wow! The Dream Machine is amazing! The game starts off slowly, but ramps up to be some of the best point-and-click adventuring to be had anywhere. And the ending was jaw-dropping. I can't believe they went there. The whole story is kind of crazy from the start, but the last level and especially the ending were bonkers. This game provides an ample challenge too. I had to cheat more than usual to finish. So, chapters 1-3 serve as essentially the first act of the story; setting things up. This part was just ok, and featured the worst level, imo, the cruise ship. Beginning with chapter 4, however, the story and puzzles start to get really good. The protagonist has to rearrange his neighbors memories of her apartment in order to progress in the level. Since a lot of the game takes place within dreams, there's a lot of dream logic incorporated to solving puzzles. It was a lot of fun pushing myself to think in more abstract ways. The finale requires using a lot of the different solutions from earlier puzzles in new ways. I don't dare reveal any specifics from chapter 5 on. It just needs to be experienced. The game takes a long time to finish too. It took probably 19 hours total from start to finish. When the first few chapters were released many years ago now, the diorama photographic quality of the levels and models was visually novel and interesting. However, since then there have been many games to incorporate this visual style much better. So, the visual style comes across as just kind of generic now, with the human characters looking like ugly dolls. But, still, the overall aesthetic is decent. If you're a genre fan, you must play this. This easily makes my personal top 5 list for best point-and-click adventures and I heartily recommend The Dream Machine!

5094653.review:
Played the first 3 episodes for now, waiting for the rest to be released.

It's a pretty good adventure game. The premise (dreams) has a lot of potential.

A couple of the puzzles were of the tedious trial-and-error kind, solved by process of elimination. And the game sometimes blocked you from taking the obvious path, just because you skipped something in between.
But for the most part they are the right mix of logic and thinking outside the box. Largely quite enjoyable!

And of course the game looks amazing. Made entirely with modeling clay and cardboard, I spent as much time admiring each set piece as I did solving its puzzles.

Even with 3 chapters released, I felt it was a bit short. I hope the two remaining chapters will be longer.

839063.review:
The Dream Machine is like if Laika, the studio behind Kubo and Coraline, were to make a point-and-click and given free reign to do something a little bit more in-depth along with its creepy and bedazzling visuals. It's an innocous presentation, but The Dream Machine explores many varying themes across its 6 chapters, some quite dark, and the realistic grounding of it, both in terms of visual and writing, serve an atmosphere that's pretty unlike anything else. 

If there's one complaint, it's that the beginning and ending are a bit poor, for different reasons. It takes too long to get started, it takes too little to end. But everything in the middle, the 85% of the experience? Just an absolute joy. 
Credit has to be given to the devs for sticking with this project for the 8 years of production. What a monumental feat, honestly. Congratulations.

40629467.review:
FANTASTIC GAME!

That this is my first Steam review is a testament to how EXTRAORDINARY I found TDM to be.  (And that's certainly not to take anything away from the Amanita games, which are among my very favorites.)  But the artistry of making a video game out of clay and other assorted materials makes the visuals amazingly impressive.  In each room or scene, I marveled anew at the attention to detail.  Nothing has been ignored, including the detailed writing in the pages of a book that is found within the game.  The puzzles are both fun and challenging, and although I did surrender to peek at a walkthrough once, doing so took nothing away from the atmospheric pace of the game.  The journey through the various dreams, as seen through the main character's eyes, is a journey well worth exploring and experiencing.  The game is a stunning example of creative ingenuity, imagination, and craftsmanship. 

Much praise has already been said about the story, the visuals, and the puzzles, but I have to add that I absolutely love the WRITING!  Other times, I have actually quit a game that had too much printed dialogue, slowing down the story and encumbering the game play.  But with TDM, I loved clicking every question and every response, often laughing aloud at the dry, witty, or sarcastic banter that followed.  One character, the knight, was very reminiscent of Monty Python, so if you enjoy that kind of humor, you're in for a real treat! And as if that is not enough, there are times that returning somewhere after a puzzle is solved sometimes offers an entirely new round of dialogue.  How cool is that?!  

It's also one of the only games where I took my time to wander around, after solving a puzzle/dream, just to re-examine the details of any one room or scene, reluctant to leave too soon.  I explored at will. It would be downright criminal to rush through any part of this hefty game, which is packed with impressive visuals, characters, and writing.  For some, the subject may seem at times a little too dark or too surreal, but for those who don't mind venturing where all is not always sweetness and light and who enjoy the irreverent, the game is real gem!  Hours and hours of game play await: a veritable bargain for this treasure.

40573230.review: Great, long and engaging story and for the most part puzzles. Not the best performance due to being made in flash I presume, but that can be overlooked.

40530776.review:
This review is for all chapters, but I had to take a long break between Chapter 5 and Chapter 6, because I didn't own Chapter 6.  I received the game through a humble bundle, and for whatever reason the 6th Chapter was not included.  Which is fine.  I don't mind paying the extra $5, but had I known I didn't have all the Chapters, I would have waited until I bought the last one before starting.

For that reason, this review is mostly based on Chapter 6 with what I sort of remember from the other Chapters.

The game is a well crafted point and click adventure game with a unique art style and competent writing.  I was anxious to finish chapter 6 and wish I hadn't waited so long

The game can get really disturbing at times, especially towards the end of Chapter 6.  One of the most disturbing parts has a non-violent option you can take, that I wasn't aware of at the time.  It's worth discovering that non-violent option, in my opinion.

Complaints:
There is one section from chapter 6 that requires you to walk around in a relatively blank space, with no indication that anything is happening.  As far as I know, you just walk around randomly until something starts happening, but it feels like a bad mechanic to me. (Upon further inspection there may be music that gets louder as your approach the target)
Something I didn't realize until after I beat the game is that there is a slider that allows you to adjust the walk speed, but it's backwards.  I just assumed it was at max speed because it was all the way to the right, but the max speed is actually all the way to the left.
When I  close the game it tells me "The Dream Machine has stopped working".  Doesn't seem to affect gameplay though.

40141169.review:
I ended up getting all 6 chapters on sale for only $10, and I kind of feel bad about it because this game is meaty. It's so well made and thought out, and just gorgeous. You can see the fingerprints on the figures and backgrounds from being hand made. Each dream is vastly different and interesting, and the puzzles are the right amount of hard.

There are unexpectedly grisly and gory scenes in this, and haunting dream imagery that is pretty creepy, so I would not recommend this for young children or if you don't like gore.  The story is very dark too, so if you liked Fran Bow, you'll enjoy this one. I probably wouldn't play it again, as it's pretty straight forward and there's only the one ending. 

I spent about 1-2 hours on each chapter and had fun just admiring the sets and exploring the dialogue. There's dark humor and jokes here and there. The main character does some shady stuff that will make you laugh out loud because WHY WOULD YOU DO THAT?! But it makes sense in the dream worlds.

Highly recommended.

40056624.review:
Обзор сразу на все части, как целую историю без спойлеров.

Наркомания ужасная. Но в итоге мне понравилось.

В начале игра начинает себя как самый обычный такой квест, раскрывая свой сюжет не сразу, а ее идея становится яснее  ближе к концу игры.
Суть в том что мысль, которую хотел передать автор раскрывается все больше именно к концу игры.

Хорошая сложность, сейчас не могу вспомнить чего-то супер необычного в плане комбинации предмет-действие, хотя  
в игре по сути мы имеем дело со снами, где все возможно. Мне пришлось пару раз обратиться к гайду-прохождению, пару моментов до которых я вряд ли вообще додумался а бы, а пару просто потому что надоело искать, об этом я еще напишу ниже, о том, как я перестал в нее играть.

Хоррор в игре связан сугубо с ее идеей и сюжетом. Тут нет выпрыгивающих скримеров, страшных зубатых рож и прочего. Не смотря на то, что вся игра сделана из пластилина, она пугает звуковым сопровождением и тем, как она себя показывает. Ох не раз я сидел весь в мурахах играя в нее.

Сложно что-то еще сказать про квест, весь геймплей состоит собирания и применения вещей в нужных местах, и диалогов с персонажами, как, впрочем, и любой другой квест. Головоломок, в плане вот тебе экран и реши на нем задачку только одна в самом начале игры, я думаю автор ее вставил туда просто для пробы.

В какой-то момент я перестал в нее играть. Дело в том, что это был один из тех моментов, когда игра создает о себе представление того, что вот он уже конец истории, осталось совсем немного, но это затягивается и затягивается... В итоге, на самом деле это был не конец, а из-за этой затянутости она меня просто выбесила и мне не удалось воспринять ее в тот момент. Игра создала впечатление того что заканчивается, я ждал конца, а она начала раскрывать ну уж совсем далекие мысли героя.
Однако, вернувшись к ней через некоторое время, я допрошел игру до конца.

В связи со спецификой рассказа, я не могу посоветовать ее каждому любителю квестов. Тут очень неоднозанчный сюжет с неоднозначными идеями. Специфика снов заставляет придумывать всевозможные решения. 
Если вы любите копаться в таких штуках, думать и размышлять об этом, по разному (глубинно) трактовать и понимать ситуации, и не считаете это все бредом, то вам эта игра определнно понравится. Я бы даже дал этой игре жанр артхауса.

Сама игра по механике хорошая, а вот идея и сюжет могут как напугать, так и привлечь игрока.

39932869.review:
Первые два эпизода интересно, начиная с третьего какая то халтура пошла (приобрёл их все). Меню в игре да и сама игра прилично тормозит местами (привет флэш технологии и оптимизации). Очень напрягают головоломки решающиеся исключительно методом перебора или тыка. Напрягают головоломки нелогичные вроде: совместите тент от солнца и стакан и получите коктейль для бара. Было несколько головоломок с пиксель хантингом, что вообще не круто.
В начале игры сильно вывозит стилизация, но корявый геймплей через несколько часов игры сводит её на нет. Неудобная система сохраниений: не ясно в каком сейве что сохранено.
Если в начале было интересно, то уже к четвёртому эпизоду игра идёт крайне натужно, запускать её просто не охото и не интересно.
В последних двух эпизодах ситуация с головоломками исправлена и проходить игру становится снова интересно, но тормоза и баги местами просто убивают всё.
Если бы разработчики хотя бы отказались от флэша, и более тщательно отсеяли бы баги, то всё было бы намного лучше.

39880574.review:
Rarely am I so impressed by a video game or movie that I go to the trouble to publicly praise it. I recently completed a computer game titled The Dream Machine, a game – nay, experience – that was, in my biased opinion, astounding.
The game is a “point-and-click” adventure, a game genre that is very easy to learn – even for people who have never even played a computer game before. The game consists of series of intuitive puzzles. The few instances that I found the game unenjoyable was when I really got stuck and was consequentially unable to progress. I admit that I did need to look online for tiny hints on 3 or 4 occurrences throughout the ≈ 20-hour adventure to bypass these roadblocks. But each time I looked for a hint, I thereafter found myself thinking, “Golly gee, I’m a dummy for not thinking of that!” So altogether, the puzzles are challenging but not so cryptic that the game ever feels unfair. The game designers found just the right balance between challenge and reward.
But what really made The Dream Machine so special was the unique artistic presentation and background music. This game is an artistic marvel that took 7 years to create, and all that effort shows in the exquisitely detailed environments and characters. It was designed using tangible, physical sculptures and models that were then animated with computer software. The story and dialogues were also very well written and neither stereotypical nor cheesy. In most video games and movies, I develop very little concern for any of the characters because they behave in a superficial or inhuman manner. That wasn’t an issue with this game. It’s amazing that this whole project was created by just two independent game designers, a few musicians, and a group of play testers.
The only real grievance I have with The Dream Machine is that a scene towards the end of the adventure seemed practically plagiarized from one of my favorite science fiction films. But considering that the game’s developers were from Sweden, perhaps they were unaware of the strong resemblance between that scene in the game and that scene in that particular (American) movie.
Although I really enjoyed The Dream Machine, be warned that this game probably won’t be enjoyable for people lacking patience of an appreciation for the weird, surrealistic artistic style of the game. And due to a few gruesome bits, it also isn’t appropriate for young people.
